In this paper, we present a novel approach to semantic segmentation using very deep fully convolutional networks (VCNNs). Our proposed method leverages the strengths of VCNNs in feature extraction and combines them with advanced techniques in spatial pyramid pooling and multi-scale features fusion to achieve state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets.

We conduct a thorough evaluation of our approach on the PASCAL VOC dataset, Cityscapes dataset, and CamVid dataset, and demonstrate significant improvements over existing methods. Our key contributions include:

1. A novel architecture design that incorporates dilated convolutions and spatial pyramid pooling to effectively capture both local and global contextual information.
2. An efficient multi-scale features fusion strategy that combines low-level, middle-level, and high-level features to improve the accuracy and robustness of semantic segmentation.
3. A comprehensive analysis of the impact of different architectural components and training parameters on performance, providing insights into the optimal design choices for VCNN-based semantic segmentation models.
4. The development of a new post-processing technique that refines the output of the network by iteratively applying a series of upsampling and convolution operations, leading to improved boundary accuracy and overall performance.

Our experimental results show that our proposed method outperforms previous state-of-the-art methods on all three datasets, achieving an mIoU of 86.5% on PASCAL VOC, 79.8% on Cityscapes, and 90.7% on CamVid. Furthermore, we perform ablation studies to validate the effectiveness of each component of our method, demonstrating the importance of dilated convolutions, spatial pyramid pooling, and multi-scale features fusion.

This work has important implications for a wide range of applications, including autonomous driving, robotics, medical imaging, and video surveillance, where accurate semantic segmentation is critical. Our findings demonstrate that VCNNs can be used to achieve high-performance semantic segmentation, and provide valuable insights for future research directions in this field.

In this paper, we present a novel approach for accelerating inference in Markov random fields (MRF) using smooth Riemannian optimization. MRFs are widely used probabilistic graphical models that capture complex dependencies between random variables. Inference in MRFs, however, is known to be computationally challenging, especially for large and complex models.

Existing inference methods for MRFs include belief propagation (BP) and Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), which are often computationally expensive and may not scale well for large datasets. In this paper, we propose an alternative approach that leverages the theory of smooth Riemannian optimization to develop an efficient and scalable inference algorithm for MRFs.

Our approach is based on the observation that the inference problem in MRFs can be formulated as a optimization problem over a Riemannian manifold. By exploiting the smooth structure of this manifold, we can develop an optimization algorithm that converges faster and more accurately than existing methods. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark datasets and show that it significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of computational efficiency and accuracy.

Our main contributions include:

* A novel formulation of the inference problem in MRFs as a smooth Riemannian optimization problem.
* An efficient optimization algorithm that leverages the smooth structure of the Riemannian manifold to accelerate inference in MRFs.
* A comprehensive evaluation of our approach on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating its superior performance compared to existing methods.

Our work has important implications for a wide range of applications, including computer vision, natural language processing, and machine learning. Specifically, it provides a new and effective way to perform inference in MRFs, which can be used to improve the performance of various machine learning models and algorithms that rely on MRFs.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to structured inference that combines the strengths of deep neural networks and random fields. Our proposed model, called the Deep-Structured Fully-Connected Random Field (DSFCRF), leverages the representational power of deep neural networks to model complex relationships between variables in a structured inference task, while also incorporating domain knowledge through a probabilistic graphical model.

The DSFCRF model is built on top of a deep neural network that learns to encode input data into a lower-dimensional representation. This encoding is then used as input to a fully-connected random field, which models the joint probability distribution over the output variables. The random field is structured using a set of conditional independence constraints, which are learned during training and enforced using a variational approximation.

We evaluate the performance of the DSFCRF model on several benchmark datasets and compare it to state-of-the-art methods for structured inference. Our results show that the DSFCRF model outperforms existing approaches in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency, while also providing more interpretable predictions. We also demonstrate the versatility of our model by applying it to a variety of tasks, including image segmentation, natural language processing, and recommendation systems.

Our main contribution is the introduction of a deep-structured fully-connected random field model that integrates the strengths of deep learning and probabilistic graphical models for structured inference. The DSFCRF model provides a powerful tool for solving complex inference problems in various domains, and its ability to incorporate domain knowledge makes it particularly useful in situations where interpretability is important.

This paper proposes a novel approach to medical image segmentation, which is robust even when trained on small-scale data with incomplete labels. Existing methods often require large amounts of labeled data to achieve high accuracy, but in many medical imaging applications, obtaining complete and accurate labeling is difficult or expensive. Our proposed method leverages recent advances in deep learning and semi-supervised learning to overcome this challenge.

We introduce a new architecture that incorporates both supervised and unsupervised learning components to effectively utilize the limited labeled data available. The supervised component uses a fully convolutional network (FCN) to learn from the labeled data, while the unsupervised component employs a variational autoencoder (VAE) to regularize the learned representations and encourage spatial consistency. We also propose a novel loss function that combines the traditional cross-entropy loss with an adversarial term to handle the class imbalance issue common in medical images.

Our experiments demonstrate that our proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art segmentation models on several benchmark datasets, including brain tumor segmentation from MRI scans and lung nodule detection from CT scans. Notably, we show that our model achieves high accuracy even when trained on only a few labeled examples per class, significantly reducing the amount of manual annotation required compared to traditional approaches.

This work has important implications for real-world medical image analysis tasks where annotated data is scarce. By enabling robust segmentation performance with minimal labeling effort, our method can accelerate research and clinical applications such as disease diagnosis, treatment planning, and monitoring.

This research paper aims to evaluate the performance of various classifiers for image segmentation in the context of eucalypt forest inventory. The accurate classification of images into different classes, such as trees, grass, and groundcover, is essential for automating the process of forest inventory and management. We compare the performance of several popular machine learning algorithms, including decision trees, random forests, support vector machines (SVMs), and neural networks, on a large dataset of aerial images captured using unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in a eucalypt forest.

Our results show that SVMs achieve the highest overall accuracy among all classifiers tested, with an average accuracy of 92.6%. Neural networks also perform well, with an average accuracy of 91.7%, but are computationally more expensive than SVMs. Decision trees and random forests have lower accuracies, at 84.3% and 85.4%, respectively. We also analyze the impact of different parameters, such as texture features, color bands, and spatial resolution, on the performance of each classifier.

The results of this study have important implications for the development of autonomous systems for forest inventory and management. Our findings suggest that SVMs and neural networks are promising approaches for image segmentation tasks in eucalypt forests, while decision trees and random forests may be less effective. Future research should focus on further optimizing these techniques and exploring new methods to improve the accuracy and efficiency of forest inventory processes.

Medical image segmentation is a crucial step in various medical applications, such as disease diagnosis, treatment planning, and monitoring. However, segmentation algorithms can be sensitive to uncertainties in the imaging process, leading to variability in the segmentation results. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a novel approach to uncertainty quantification in medical image segmentation using normalizing flows.

Normalizing flows are a type of generative model that transform a simple probability distribution into a complex distribution using a series of invertible transformations. In the context of medical image segmentation, normalizing flows can be used to model the uncertainty in the segmentation process and generate a distribution over the possible segmentation outcomes. This allows for the quantification of uncertainty in the segmentation results, which can be useful for decision-making and improving the accuracy of the segmentation algorithms.

The proposed approach is evaluated on various medical imaging modalities, including MRI, CT, and PET scans. The results show that the normalizing flow-based approach outperforms traditional uncertainty quantification methods, such as Monte Carlo dropout and Bayesian neural networks, in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency. Additionally, the approach is able to capture complex patterns in the data, such as spatial correlations and hierarchical structures, which can be useful for identifying features that are indicative of certain diseases or conditions.

The paper also includes a thorough analysis of the effects of different components of the normalizing flow on the uncertainty quantification performance. The results show that the choice of flow architecture and the number of layers have a significant impact on the accuracy and computational efficiency of the approach. Furthermore, the paper investigates the use of different likelihood models, such as Gaussian and Student's t- Distributions, and shows that the choice of likelihood model can affect the performance of the approach.

Overall, this paper demonstrates the potential of normalizing flows for uncertainty quantification in medical image segmentation. The proposed approach has important implications for various medical applications, such as disease diagnosis, treatment planning, and monitoring, where quantifying the uncertainty in segmentation results is crucial for making informed decisions.

In this paper, we explore the concept of frame reference and its properties as a 4-invariant in various physical and mathematical contexts. We begin by examining the definition of frame reference and its relationship to the concept of invariance. We then delve into the mathematical framework of differential geometry, where we demonstrate that the frame reference can be represented as a 4-invariant, which is a mathematical object that remains unchanged under certain transformations.

We continue by examining the physical implications of this result, showing that the 4-invariance of frame reference has significant consequences for our understanding of the nature of space and time. We discuss how this concept can be applied to various physical phenomena, such as the behavior of particles and fields, the curvature of spacetime, and the nature of gravitational waves.

Furthermore, we explore the relationship between the 4-invariance of frame reference and other fundamental concepts in physics, such as Lorentz invariance and the principle of relativity. We show that these concepts are closely related to the 4-invariance of frame reference and can be understood in terms of it.

Finally, we conclude by discussing the broader implications of our results, both for our understanding of the fundamental laws of physics and for the development of new technologies that rely on the manipulation of frame reference. We argue that a deeper understanding of the 4-invariance of frame reference has the potential to revolutionize our understanding of the universe and open up new avenues for exploration and discovery.

Overall, our paper provides a comprehensive examination of the 4-invariance of frame reference and its significance in modern physics. We demonstrate that this concept has far-reaching implications for our understanding of the nature of space and time, and we highlight the potential for further research and discovery in this exciting area of study.

In this paper, we explore the connection between free particles and complex KdV breathers through the use of isospectral deformation. We show that by appropriately deforming the spectrum of the free particle Hamiltonian, we can generate a family of bounded breathers, which we refer to as "complex KdV breathers," that display rich and interesting dynamical behavior.

Our approach is based on the method of isospectral deformation, which involves deforming the Hamiltonian of a physical system in a way that preserves its spectral properties. By applying this method to the free particle Hamiltonian, we are able to generate a family of Hamiltonians that are isospectral to the free particle Hamiltonian, but exhibit a rich variety of dynamical behaviors.

We demonstrate that the complex KdV breathers obtained through this process exhibit a range of interesting properties, including temporal and spatial localization, wave-like behavior, and self-similarity. We also show that these breathers are related to the KdV equation, a well-known nonlinear partial differential equation that describes the evolution of shallow water waves, and that they exhibit similarities with other nonlinear wave systems, such as the nonlinear Schrdinger equation.

Our results provide a new perspective on the relationship between free particles and complex breathers, and demonstrate the power of isospectral deformation as a tool for generating novel and interesting physical systems. They also highlight the potential of complexity arising from simplicity, as the rich dynamical behavior of the complex KdV breathers emerges from the simplicity of the free particle Hamiltonian.

This work has implications for a wide range of fields, including condensed matter physics, optics, and fluid dynamics, where the behavior of nonlinear wave systems is of great interest. The methods we develop here may also be applicable to other physical systems, and could potentially lead to the discovery of new and interesting phenomena.

RatLesNetv2: A Fully Convolutional Network for Rodent Brain Lesion Segmentation

Abstract:

Accurate segmentation of brain lesions in rodents is crucial for studying the progression and treatment of various neurological disorders. However, manual segmentation is time-consuming and subjective, leading to variability and potential bias in downstream analyses. To address this challenge, we propose RatLesNetv2, a fully convolutional network (FCN) designed specifically for rodent brain lesion segmentation.

RatLesNetv2 builds upon our previous work, RatLesNet, by incorporating additional features and architectural improvements. The network utilizes a combination of convolutional and max-pooling layers to extract spatial and contextual information from T2-weighted magnetic resonance images (MRI). We introduce a new multi-scale feature fusion module that integrates features from different resolutions, enabling the network to capture both local and global patterns. Additionally, we incorporate a spatial attention mechanism that focuses the network's attention on the most relevant regions, improving segmentation accuracy.

We evaluate RatLesNetv2 on a dataset of 160 rat brain MRI scans, comparing its performance to RatLesNet and a state-of-the-art FCN, U-Net. Our results show that RatLesNetv2 outperforms both RatLesNet and U-Net in terms of segmentation accuracy, with a mean Dice similarity coefficient of 0.83. We also perform a series of ablation studies to analyze the contributions of the key components in RatLesNetv2, demonstrating the effectiveness of the multi-scale feature fusion module and spatial attention mechanism.

RatLesNetv2 represents a significant step forward in rodent brain lesion segmentation, offering improved accuracy and efficiency. The network's fully convolutional architecture and novel features make it a valuable tool for researchers studying brain disorders in rodent models, facilitating the analysis of large-scale datasets and enabling the development of new treatments.

LT-Net: Label Transfer by Learning Reversible Voxel-wise Correspondence for One-shot Medical Image Segmentation

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to one-shot medical image segmentation using label transfer learning. Our method, called LT-Net, leverages reversible voxel-wise correspondence between source and target images to learn a mapping that can be used to transfer labels from the source domain to the target domain. This is achieved through a combination of adversarial training and contrastive learning, which enables our model to learn a robust representation that generalizes well across different datasets. We evaluate our method on several publicly available medical imaging datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in comparison to state-of-the-art methods. The main contributions of this work are:

* A novel approach to one-shot medical image segmentation using label transfer learning
* Introduction of a new architecture that learns reversible voxel-wise correspondence between source and target images
* Demonstration of the effectiveness of our method on several publicly available medical imaging datasets

Our proposed method has important implications for medical image analysis tasks where annotated data is scarce or difficult to obtain. By enabling the transfer of labels from well-annotated sources to unannotated targets, LT-Net has the potential to significantly reduce the amount of manual annotation required for medical image segmentation tasks.

This paper presents a novel approach to video-based eye tracking that leverages recursive estimation of pupil characteristics to achieve robust and accurate tracking in real-world environments. Existing methods often struggle with varying lighting conditions, eye occlusion, and other challenges that compromise the accuracy and reliability of eye tracking. In contrast, our proposed method uses a recursive algorithm that continuously updates an estimate of the pupil center and radius based on the current video frame and previous estimates.

The proposed method is evaluated using a dataset of videos captured in diverse indoor and outdoor settings, and the results demonstrate superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods. Specifically, our approach achieves an average precision of 95% and recall of 90% across all videos, while existing methods exhibit significant decreases in performance under similar conditions. Additionally, we perform a series of ablation studies to analyze the contributions of various components of our method, providing insights into the effectiveness of different design choices.

Our findings have important implications for a wide range of applications, including human-computer interaction, psychology research, and medical diagnosis. The demonstrated robustness and accuracy of our video-based eye tracking method make it suitable for use in real-world scenarios, where reliable eye tracking is crucial for accurately assessing cognitive processes, emotional states, and visual attention.

This paper addresses the sensor location problem, which is a critical task in various fields such as engineering, robotics, and computer science. The goal is to determine the optimal placement of sensors or detection devices in order to maximize their effectiveness in detecting events or phenomena of interest while minimizing costs and other resources.

The authors identify several characteristic properties of optimal solutions to the sensor location problem, including:

1. Minimality: Optimal solutions typically involve the minimum number of sensors necessary to achieve the desired level of detection performance.
2. Uniformity: Optimal solutions often exhibit uniform spacing between sensors, reducing the likelihood of redundant measurements and improving overall efficiency.
3. Robustness: Optimal solutions are often robust to variations in the environment, meaning that they continue to perform well even when there are changes in the target being detected or other external factors.
4. Adaptability: Optimal solutions frequently incorporate adaptive features that enable them to adjust to changing conditions over time, ensuring continued optimal performance.
5. Hierarchical structure: Many optimal solutions exhibit a hierarchical structure, with sensors organized into clusters or arrays that allow for greater flexibility and responsiveness.
6. Non-uniform sampling: In certain cases,optimal solutions may employ non-uniform sampling strategies, where sensors are concentrated in areas of higher importance or likelihood of detection.
7. Addressing trade-offs: Optimal solutions must balance competing objectives,such as cost versus detection probability,or resolution versus coverage,and thus these solutionsetttings often reveal important trade-off relationships.
8. Model-based optimization: Optimal solutions usually result from model-based optimization techniques that take into account the specific characteristics of the monitoring environment,detection algorithms ,and sensor capabilities.
9. Contextual awareness: They often consider contextual information like topological maps, weather patterns,or prior knowledge about potential sources of interest.
10. Iterative improvement: Finally, many optimal solutions are developed through iterative processes involving continuous refinement based on feedback data and real-world observations.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to semi-supervised medical image segmentation called SimCVD, which stands for Simple Contrastive Voxel-Wise Representation Distillation. Semi-supervised learning is a challenging task, particularly in medical image segmentation, where labeled data is scarce and expensive to obtain. SimCVD addresses this challenge by leveraging contrastive learning and representation distillation to train a segmentation model using both labeled and unlabeled data.

The key innovation of SimCVD is the use of a contrastive loss function to train a voxel-wise representation distillation model. This allows the model to learn a robust representation space that is agnostic to the specific segmentation task, yet still captures the underlying structure of the data. We demonstrate the effectiveness of SimCVD on several publicly available medical imaging datasets, including brain tumor segmentation and lung segmentation.

Our results show that SimCVD outperforms traditional semi-supervised methods, such as self-supervised pre-training and transfer learning, as well as other state-of-the-art methods that use contrastive learning for medical image segmentation. Additionally, we show that SimCVD can be used with various backbone networks and does not require significant modifications to the existing network architecture.

Overall, SimCVD has the potential to significantly improve the accuracy and efficiency of medical image segmentation in situations where labeled data is limited. Its simplicity and generalizability make it an attractive approach for a wide range of medical image segmentation tasks.

In this paper, we present a comprehensive performance evaluation of deep learning networks for semantic segmentation of traffic stereo-pair images. We explore the use of various deep learning architectures, including convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs), for semantic segmentation of traffic scenes from stereo-pair images. We evaluate the performance of these networks using a large dataset of stereo-pair images captured from various traffic scenarios, and compare their performance using different evaluation metrics.

Our results show that CNNs outperform RNNs in terms of segmentation accuracy, with the best-performing CNN achieving an accuracy of 93.6%. We also analyze the effect of different parameters, such as image resolution, batch size, and number of epochs, on the segmentation performance. Our results indicate that increasing the image resolution and batch size improves segmentation accuracy, while increasing the number of epochs has a diminishing effect on performance.

We also perform a thorough analysis of the segmentation results, including a class-wise analysis of the errors and a study of the impact of different object classes on the overall segmentation accuracy. Our results show that the CNNs struggle with certain object classes, such as pedestrians and motorcycles, and that improving the segmentation accuracy of these classes is crucial for achieving high overall segmentation accuracy.

Our findings have important implications for the development of autonomous driving systems, which rely heavily on accurate semantic segmentation of traffic scenes. We demonstrate that deep learning networks can achieve high segmentation accuracy on stereo-pair images, but that further research is needed to improve the accuracy of certain object classes. Our results also highlight the importance of carefully selecting the appropriate deep learning architecture, hyperparameters, and evaluation metrics for semantic segmentation tasks.

Overall, this paper provides a comprehensive evaluation of deep learning networks for semantic segmentation of traffic stereo-pair images, and provides valuable insights for the development of autonomous driving systems.

Histopathology image segmentation is a crucial task in medical image analysis, but it remains challenging due to the variability in tissue morphology, staining, and image quality. Deep learning methods have shown promising results in this task, but they require a large amount of annotated data, which is time-consuming and expensive to obtain. In this paper, we propose a novel approach called Constrained Deep Weak Supervision (CDWS) to segment histopathology images with minimal annotated data.

CDWS combines the strengths of deep learning and weak supervision to segment histopathology images. Weak supervision refers to the use of easily obtainable, low-quality annotations, such as image-level class labels or rough segmentation masks, to train deep neural networks. By incorporating domain-specific knowledge and constraints into the training process, CDWS can improve the accuracy of weakly supervised deep learning models and reduce the need for high-quality annotations.

We evaluate CDWS on several histopathology datasets and compare it with state-of-the-art weakly supervised segmentation methods. Our results show that CDWS outperforms these methods in terms of segmentation accuracy, demonstrating its effectiveness in leveraging large amounts of weakly annotated data for histopathology image segmentation. We also perform a series of ablation studies to analyze the contribution of different components in CDWS, providing insights into the design of weakly supervised segmentation models.

The main contributions of this paper are:

1. The proposal of CDWS, a novel approach to histopathology image segmentation that combines deep learning and weak supervision.
2. The development of a domain-specific constraint module that incorporates knowledge from histopathology experts to improve the accuracy of weakly supervised segmentation models.
3. The extensive evaluation of CDWS on several histopathology datasets, demonstrating its superiority over state-of-the-art weakly supervised segmentation methods.

Brain tumor segmentation is a crucial task in medical image analysis, as it enables clinicians to accurately diagnose and treat various types of brain tumors. In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning model that integrates Fully Convolutional Neural Networks (FCNNs) and Conditional Random Fields (CRFs) for brain tumor segmentation from magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans.

Our proposed model consists of two main components: an FCNN that extracts features from MRI scans, and a CRF that refines the segmentation results. The FCNN is trained to learn hierarchical representations of the input data, while the CRF models the spatial relationships between neighboring pixels and enforces label consistency across the image. We use a patch-based training strategy to optimize the model's performance, where each patch is annotated with a binary mask indicating the presence or absence of a tumor.

We evaluate our model on a dataset of 160 MRI scans, including both high-grade and low-grade tumors. Our experiments show that the integration of FCNNs and CRFs leads to significant improvements in segmentation accuracy compared to using either approach alone. Specifically, our model achieves an average Dice coefficient of 0.83 and an average pixel accuracy of 93.4%, outperforming existing state-of-the-art methods.

Moreover, we perform a series of ablation studies to analyze the contributions of different components in our model. We find that the combination of FCNNs and CRFs yields better segmentation results than using either approach separately, demonstrating the complementary nature of these two techniques. Additionally, we investigate the effectiveness of different design choices, such as the number of layers in the FCNN and the size of the CRF grid, and provide insights into their impact on performance.

Overall, our work presents a powerful deep learning model for brain tumor segmentation that leverages the strengths of both FCNNs and CRFs. In this paper, we present a novel approach for segmenting hierarchically-nested classes in images, using a multi-level activation mechanism. Traditional segmentation methods struggle with accurately identifying objects that are nested within others, as they are limited to a single level of activation. Our proposed method addresses this limitation by introducing a hierarchical framework that allows for the detection of objects at multiple levels of granularity.

Our approach uses a combination of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and a novel activation function, called the Hierarchical Refinement Activation (HRA) function. The HRA function allows the network to learn a hierarchy of object classes, where each class is defined by a set of nested bounding boxes. The network learns to activate the bounding boxes at multiple levels, enabling the detection of objects at different levels of nesting.

We evaluate our method on several benchmark datasets, including PASCAL VOC and COCO, and show that it outperforms traditional segmentation methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in segmenting objects with varying levels of nesting, and show that it can handle complex scenarios with nested objects of different sizes and orientations.

Our main contributions are:

* A novel multi-level activation mechanism for segmenting hierarchically-nested classes
* A new activation function, called the Hierarchical Refinement Activation (HRA) function, which enables the detection of objects at multiple levels of granularity
* An evaluation of our method on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating its superior performance compared to traditional segmentation methods
* A demonstration of the effectiveness of our method in handling complex scenarios with nested objects of different sizes and orientations.

Overall, our approach provides a significant improvement in the accuracy and efficiency of object segmentation, and has important implications for a wide range of applications, including object recognition, scene understanding, and robotic vision.

This paper investigates the impact of ground truth annotation quality on the performance of semantic image segmentation of traffic conditions. Semantic image segmentation is a critical task in various computer vision applications, including traffic condition monitoring. However, the accuracy of semantic segmentation models heavily relies on the quality of the ground truth annotations. In this study, we evaluate the effect of ground truth annotation quality on the performance of a state-of-the-art semantic image segmentation model for traffic conditions.

We created a dataset of images captured from traffic cameras and annotated them with four different levels of ground truth quality: high, medium, low, and random. We then trained and evaluated the semantic segmentation model on each annotated dataset. Our results show that the model's performance significantly decreases as the ground truth annotation quality decreases. Specifically, the model's accuracy drops by 12.5% and 27.3% when the annotation quality is reduced from high to medium and low, respectively. Moreover, we found that the model's performance is heavily affected by the quality of annotations for certain classes, such as pedestrians and motorcycles.

Our findings highlight the importance of high-quality ground truth annotations for training accurate semantic image segmentation models for traffic conditions. We also demonstrate that the model's performance can be improved by incorporating additional data augmentation techniques, such as flipping and color jittering, to reduce the impact of annotation quality on the model's accuracy.

Our study has significant implications for the development of computer vision systems for traffic condition monitoring. We demonstrate that investing in high-quality ground truth annotations is crucial for achieving accurate semantic segmentation models. Moreover, our findings suggest that combining high-quality annotations with data augmentation techniques can further improve the model's performance. This study contributes to the development of more accurate and robust computer vision systems for traffic condition monitoring, which can ultimately improve road safety and traffic efficiency.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach for out-of-distribution (OOD) detection in multi-label datasets using the latent space of a $$-VAE. Our approach leverages the ability of Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) to learn a continuous and structured representation of data in a lower-dimensional latent space. By modifying the VAE's objective function to incorporate a hyperparameter $$, we can control the balance between the reconstruction loss and the KL-divergence term, leading to a more disentangled and meaningful latent space.

We evaluate the performance of our method on several benchmark datasets and show that it outperforms existing OOD detection methods in terms of detection accuracy and robustness to different types of attacks. We also perform an ablation study to analyze the effectiveness of the $$-VAE's latent space in OOD detection and demonstrate that it is superior to other latent space representations, such as PCA and t-SNE.

Our main contribution is the introduction of a $$-VAE-based OOD detection method that leverages the benefits of both VAEs and $$-VAE's latent space. Our approach is simple to implement, does not require any additional training data or annotations, and can be applied to various types of datasets. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of our method, making it a promising solution for OOD detection in real-world applications.

This paper presents a comprehensive overview of computer stereo vision and its applications in autonomous driving. The paper begins by discussing the fundamentals of stereo vision, including the principles of binocular disparity and depth perception, and how these concepts can be applied to computer vision.

The authors then delve into the specific techniques used in computer stereo vision, such as feature extraction, matching, and 3D reconstruction. They also explore the various algorithms and methods employed in stereo vision, including traditional methods like block-matching algorithms and more modern approaches like deep learning-based methods.

The paper then shifts its focus to the application of stereo vision in autonomous driving, highlighting its role in obstacle detection, lane departure warning, and motion forecasting. The authors discuss the challenges associated with using stereo vision in real-world scenarios, such as varying lighting conditions, shadows, and occlusions, and propose solutions to address these issues.

Finally, the paper provides an extensive evaluation of the performance of stereo vision systems in autonomous driving, using both simulated and real-world data sets. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of stereo vision in detecting objects and predicting their motion, even in complex scenarios.

Overall, this paper serves as a valuable resource for researchers and practitioners working in the field of computer vision and autonomous driving, providing a thorough understanding of the principles and practices of computer stereo vision and its applications in vehicle autonomy.

The abstract of an academic paper provides a concise summary of the research work, highlighting its key contributions and findings. Here's a possible abstract for the paper titled "SCOR: Software-defined Constrained Optimal Routing Platform for SDN":

Software-Defined Networking (SDN) has revolutionized network management by decoupling control plane from data plane, enabling centralized management and programmability. However, existing SDN routing platforms often fall short in optimizing network resource utilization due to their limited ability to handle complex constraints and dynamic changes in network conditions. This paper presents SCOR, a software-defined constrained optimal routing platform that leverages recent advances in linear programming and optimization techniques to provide efficient and flexible routing solutions for SDN networks.

SCOR addresses the limitations of traditional routing approaches by incorporating rich constraint models that capture network heterogeneity, scalability, and performance requirements. Our platform enables network administrators to specify high-level policies and objectives, while automatically computing optimal routes that satisfy these constraints while minimizing network resources usage. We evaluate SCOR using several realistic testbeds and compare it with state-of-the-art SDN routing platforms, demonstrating significant improvements in terms of network utilization, latency, and resilience.

The main contribution of this paper is the design and implementation of SCOR, which offers a novel approach to software-defined routing that combines the benefits of centralized management, constraint satisfaction, and optimized resource allocation. Our results demonstrate the effectiveness of SCOR in various scenarios, including multi-tenancy, traffic engineering, and network failures. By providing a more intelligent and adaptive routing framework, SCOR paves the way for future SDN applications that can efficiently manage growing network complexity and dynamics.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to domain adaptation for image segmentation tasks, which we term source-relaxed domain adaptation. This method leverages the strengths of both source and target domains to improve the performance of the segmentation model in the target domain.

Existing domain adaptation methods often rely on aligning the source and target domains through adversarial training or domain confusion techniques. However, these methods can be limited by the quality of the labeled data available in the target domain. In contrast, our proposed method utilizes unsupervised learning to adapt the segmentation model to the target domain using only a small number of labeled images from the target domain.

The key insight behind our approach is that the segmentation model's predictions on the source domain can serve as a regularization tool to guide the learning process in the target domain. By relaxing the source domain's supervision signal, we allow the model to learn from both the source and target domains while still incorporating knowledge from the source domain. This leads to improved performance compared to traditional domain adaptation methods.

We evaluate our proposed approach on several benchmark datasets, including Cityscapes, PASCAL VOC, and COCO. The results show that our method outperforms existing domain adaptation models, especially when the amount of labeled target data is limited. We also perform ablation studies to analyze the effectiveness of different components of our approach, providing insights into the role of each component in improving segmentation performance.

Our contributions are summarized as follows:

* We introduce a novel domain adaptation approach called source-relaxed domain adaptation, which leverages both the source and target domains to improve image segmentation performance.
* Our method uses a simple yet effective way to integrate information from the source domain with the target domain during training.
* Extensive experiments demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art domain adaptation methods on multiple benchmark datasets, particularly when dealing with limited labeled data in the target domain.

In this paper, we explore the concept of slack and margin rescaling as convex extensions of supermodular functions. Supermodular functions are widely used in machine learning and optimization to model a variety of problems, including set cover, facility location, and linear programming. However, these functions are not always convex, which can limit their applicability in certain settings.

To address this issue, we propose two novel techniques, slack rescaling and margin rescaling, that extend supermodular functions to convex functions while preserving their original properties. We show that these techniques can be applied to a broad class of supermodular functions, including those with non-differentiable or non-concave marginal gains.

We demonstrate the effectiveness of our methods through experiments on several real-world datasets and compare them to existing approaches, such as convex relaxations and gradient-based optimization. Our results show that slack and margin rescaling significantly improve upon previous methods in terms of computational efficiency and solution quality.

Our work has important implications for a wide range of applications, including resource allocation, scheduling, and feature selection. By providing efficient and effective ways to optimize supermodular functions, we enable the use of these functions in a broader range of contexts, leading to better decision-making and improved outcomes.

In summary, this paper introduces slack and margin rescaling as powerful tools for extending supermodular functions to convex functions, enabling their application in new domains and improving the efficiency and accuracy of optimization algorithms.

Anemia is a condition characterized by a decrease in the number of red blood cells or hemoglobin in the body, which can lead to pallor, fatigue, and shortness of breath. Early detection of anemia is crucial for effective treatment and prevention of complications. In this paper, we propose a computer-aided detection system for anemia-like pallor using machine learning techniques.

Our approach involves analyzing facial images to detect pallor caused by anemia. We first extract facial features from the images and then apply a machine learning algorithm to classify the images as either pallor or non-pallor. We evaluated the performance of our system using a dataset of facial images with known anemia status.

The results show that our system achieved an accuracy of 90.1% in detecting anemia-like pallor, significantly outperforming human observation. We also compared the performance of our system with other machine learning algorithms and found that it outperformed them in terms of accuracy and efficiency.

Our study demonstrates the potential of computer-aided detection of anemia-like pallor using machine learning techniques. The system has the advantage of being non-invasive, inexpensive, and fast, making it a promising tool for early detection of anemia in various clinical and non-clinical settings. Future work includes refining the system to improve its accuracy and expanding its capabilities to detect other signs of anemia.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to probabilistic image segmentation, called Tree-Cut, which leverages the concept of tree-based data structures to efficiently partition an image into its constituent parts. Existing methods for probabilistic image segmentation often suffer from computational complexity and limitations in scalability, particularly when dealing with large images or complex segmentation tasks.

The Tree-Cut algorithm addresses these limitations by utilizing a hierarchical tree structure to represent the image and its possible segmentations. The tree is constructed by recursively partitioning the image into smaller regions, with each node in the tree representing a subset of the image pixels. The tree is then used to efficiently compute the probability distribution over the possible segmentations, using a propagation-based algorithm that combinesinformation from neighboring nodes.

We demonstrate the effectiveness of Tree-Cut through experiments on several benchmark datasets, comparing its performance to state-of-the-art methods for probabilistic image segmentation. Our results show that Tree-Cut achieves superior accuracy and significantly faster computation times than existing methods, making it a promising approach for large-scale image segmentation tasks. Additionally, we analyze the effect of various parameters on the performance of Tree-Cut, providing insights into the trade-offs between accuracy and efficiency in probabilistic image segmentation.

Overall, Tree-Cut represents a significant advancement in probabilistic image segmentation, offering a scalable and accurate solution for partitioning complex images into their constituent parts. Its hierarchical tree structure and propagation-based algorithm enable efficient computation and effective handling of large datasets, making it a valuable tool for a wide range of applications in computer vision and related fields.

PP-LinkNet: Improving Semantic Segmentation of High Resolution Satellite Imagery with Multi-stage Training

Abstract:

Semantic segmentation of high resolution satellite imagery is a challenging task due to the large amount of data, high computational costs, and the need for accurate labeling. In this paper, we propose a novel approach called PP-LinkNet, which leverages multi-stage training to improve the accuracy and efficiency of semantic segmentation. PP-LinkNet combines a pyramid-based feature extractor with a link-based labeling strategy to simultaneously segment objects at multiple scales.

The pyramid-based feature extractor generates features at multiple resolutions, allowing the model to capture both local and global context. The link-based labeling strategy creates a graph-based representation of the image, where pixels are linked to their neighboring pixels based on their similarity. This allows the model to propagate labels efficiently and accurately, reducing the need for manual labeling.

We evaluate PP-LinkNet on two high resolution satellite imagery datasets and show significant improvements in accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our experiments demonstrate that PP-LinkNet achieves a balance between accuracy and efficiency, making it a viable solution for large-scale semantic segmentation tasks.

The main contributions of this paper are:

1. PP-LinkNet: A novel approach for semantic segmentation of high resolution satellite imagery that combines a pyramid-based feature extractor and a link-based labeling strategy.
2. A multi-stage training method that improves the accuracy and efficiency of semantic segmentation.
3. An extensive evaluation of PP-LinkNet on two high resolution satellite imagery datasets, demonstrating its superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.

Overall, PP-LinkNet presents a significant advancement in the field of semantic segmentation, providing a more accurate and efficient approach for analyzing high resolution satellite imagery. The proposed method has important applications in various fields such as environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster response.

In this paper, we present a novel approach to entity segmentation that allows for open-world recognition, meaning that the model can identify entities that are not present in the training data. This is achieved by introducing an additional branch to the model that predicts the probability that a given region contains an unknown entity. The model is trained on a dataset that includes both labeled and unlabeled regions, and the unknown entity branch is trained to distinguish between known and unknown entities based on their context. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and show that it outperforms traditional closed-world entity segmentation methods, which assume that all entities present in the training data are known. Our approach also exhibits improved performance in scenarios where the training data is incomplete or contains mislabeled entities. We demonstrate the practical application of our method in a real-world scenario, where we use it to detect and segment entities in a video stream from a self-driving car. The results show that our approach can accurately segment entities that are not present in the training data, including pedestrians, cars, and road signs.

This paper proposes a novel variational image segmentation model that integrates normalized cuts with adaptive similarity and spatial regularization. The proposed model aims to overcome the limitations of traditional segmentation techniques that rely on hand-crafted features and fixed parameters, which can lead to suboptimal performance in certain applications.

The proposed model formulates image segmentation as a variational optimization problem, where the objective function combines a normalized cut criterion with an adaptive similarity measure and spatial regularization terms. The adaptive similarity measure allows the model to adapt to the changing similarity between pixels in the image, while the spatial regularization terms enforce smoothness and coherence in the segmentation results.

The proposed model is optimized using a novel iterative algorithm that alternates between computing the normalized cut and updating the parameters of the similarity measure and regularization terms. The algorithm is efficient and scalable, making it feasible to apply the model to large images.

Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed model in segmenting images with complex structures and varying levels of noise. The proposed model outperforms state-of-the-art segmentation techniques in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

The main contributions of this paper are:

* A novel variational image segmentation model that integrates normalized cuts with adaptive similarity and spatial regularization
* An efficient iterative algorithm for optimizing the proposed model
* Thorough experimental evaluation demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed model in various scenarios

The proposed model has important implications for a wide range of applications, including object recognition, tracking, and scene understanding. The adaptive similarity measure and spatial regularization terms make the model robust to variations in image quality and structure, making it a valuable tool for real-world applications.

In this paper, we propose a fast graph-cut based optimization method for practical dense deformable registration of volume images. Dense deformable registration is a fundamental problem in image registration, where the goal is to establish a mapping between two images that not only aligns them, but also accounts for the underlying deformations in the images. Existing methods for dense deformable registration are often limited by their computational complexity and lack of scalability, making them impractical for large-scale applications.

Our proposed method leverages the strengths of graph-cut optimization to efficiently solve the dense deformable registration problem. Graph-cut optimization is a powerful technique that can efficiently handle complex energy functions and has been successfully applied to a variety of image processing tasks. By formulating the dense deformable registration problem as a graph-cut problem, we are able to efficiently optimize the registration process, achieving state-of-the-art performance in terms of both accuracy and speed.

Our proposed method is validated on several large-scale datasets, including 3D brain imaging data and 2D cardiac imaging data. The results demonstrate that our method outperforms existing methods in terms of both registration accuracy and computational efficiency. Specifically, our method achieves a average registration error of 1.2% and 1.5% for 3D brain imaging data and 2D cardiac imaging data, respectively, while reducing the computational time by a factor of 10 compared to existing methods.

The main contribution of this paper is the development of a fast graph-cut based optimization method for practical dense deformable registration of volume images. Our method demonstrates superior performance in terms of both accuracy and speed, making it a promising solution for large-scale image registration applications. The proposed method has the potential to enable new applications in various fields such as medical imaging, computer vision, and machine learning, where the ability to efficiently align and compare large images is critical.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach for nuclear segmentation in digital pathology images using sparse coding driven deep decision tree ensembles. Nuclear segmentation is a crucial step in cancer diagnosis and treatment, but it remains a challenging task due to the variability in nuclear size, shape, and staining intensity. To address this challenge, we leverage the strengths of both sparse coding and deep learning to develop a robust and accurate segmentation method.

Our approach consists of two main components: a sparse coding model and a deep decision tree ensemble. The sparse coding model is used to extract discriminative features from the input images, while the deep decision tree ensemble is used to classify the pixels into nuclear and non-nuclear regions. The sparse coding model is trained on a set of representative images and learns to represent the images as a sparse linear combination of a set of basis functions. The deep decision tree ensemble is then trained on the feature representations obtained from the sparse coding model, and it learns to classify the pixels based on their similarity to the basis functions.

We evaluate our approach on a large dataset of digital pathology images and compare it to several state-of-the-art segmentation methods. Our results show that our approach outperforms the compared methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency. We also perform a series of ablation studies to analyze the contributions of the different components of our approach, and we find that the combination of sparse coding and deep decision tree ensemble is essential for achieving high accuracy.

Our work has important implications for cancer diagnosis and treatment, as accurate nuclear segmentation can help pathologists to identify tumorous regions and determine the effectiveness of treatments. Moreover, our approach has the potential to be extended to other image segmentation tasks, such as segmenting other types of cells or tissues, and it can be used to improve the performance of deep learning models in medical image analysis.

In this paper, we explore the approximation of quantum gates using lattices. Quantum computing relies on the ability to manipulate quantum states using quantum gates, which are fundamental operations that preserve the principles of quantum mechanics. However, implementing quantum gates exactly is a challenging task, especially for large-scale quantum systems.

To address this challenge, we propose a novel approach based on lattices, which are geometric structures that have been widely used in cryptography and coding theory. By exploiting the properties of lattices, we show that it is possible to approximate quantum gates with high accuracy using a finite number of lattice operations.

Our approach is based on the observation that quantum gates can be represented as linear transformations on the Hilbert space of quantum states. By discretizing the Hilbert space using a lattice, we can approximate these linear transformations using lattice operations, such as addition and multiplication by a scalar. We demonstrate that this approach can be used to approximate a wide range of quantum gates, including those that are difficult to implement exactly, such as the Toffoli gate and the controlled-NOT gate.

We evaluate the performance of our approach using a variety of metrics, including fidelity and gate infidelity. Our results show that our lattice-based approach can achieve high accuracy for a wide range of quantum gates, and outperforms existing methods in certain regimes. We also discuss the limitations of our approach and outline strategies for improving its accuracy and efficiency.

Our work has important implications for the development of practical quantum computing systems. By providing a new way to approximate quantum gates using lattices, we demonstrate that it is possible to reduce the resources required for quantum computing, such as the number of qubits and the precision of quantum control. This could help to overcome some of the challenges associated with building large-scale quantum computers, and bring us closer to the realization of practical applications of quantum computing.

In this paper, we consider the problem of parameter learning for log-supermodular distributions, which are a class of probability distributions that generalize the classical notion of log-concave distributions. We propose a new algorithmic framework for estimating the parameters of a log-supermodular distribution from samples, based on the concept of iterative minimization of the Kullback-Leibler divergence. Our approach is inspired by the success of methods such as Expectation-Maximization (EM) and Variational Inference (VI), but is specifically tailored to handle the non-convex nature of the log-supermodular likelihood function.

We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method through experiments on synthetic and real-world data sets, and show that it outperforms existing approaches in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency. Additionally, we provide theoretical guarantees for the convergence behavior of our algorithm, and establish connections between log-supermodular distributions and other classes of probabilistic models, such as log-concave and Gaussian distributions.

Our work has important implications for a wide range of applications, including image segmentation, natural language processing, and machine learning in general. By enabling efficient estimation of log-supermodular distribution parameters, we open up new possibilities for modeling complex dependencies and relationships in data, and contribute to the development of more powerful and flexible statistical inference tools.

ACE-Net: Biomedical Image Segmentation with Augmented Contracting and Expansive Paths

Abstract:

Biomedical image segmentation is a critical task in medical imaging analysis, with applications in disease diagnosis, treatment planning, and monitoring. Deep learning-based methods have shown promising results in segmenting biomedical images, but they often suffer from limited accuracy and robustness, particularly when dealing with complex and varied images. In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning architecture called ACE-Net, which stands for Augmented Contracting and Expansive Paths, to improve the accuracy and robustness of biomedical image segmentation.

ACE-Net is designed to address two main limitations of existing deep learning-based segmentation methods: (1) the lack of effective feature extraction and representation, and (2) the inability to handle complex and varied image structures. To address these limitations, ACE-Net introduces three key components: (1) augmented contracting paths, (2) expansive paths, and (3) feature pyramid networks.

Augmented contracting paths are designed to enhance feature extraction and representation by incorporating multi-scale and multi-orientation information into the network. Expansive paths are used to expand the receptive field of the network, enabling it to capture complex and varied image structures. Feature pyramid networks are employed to fuse low-level, middle-level, and high-level features, improving the network's ability to capture both local and global information.

ACE-Net is evaluated on several publicly available biomedical image segmentation datasets, including brain tumor segmentation, liver segmentation, and lung segmentation. The experimental results demonstrate that ACE-Net outperforms several state-of-the-art segmentation methods in terms of both accuracy and robustness. Specifically, ACE-Net achieves an average dice similarity coefficient of 0.83 on the brain tumor segmentation dataset, an average dice similarity coefficient of 0.93 on the liver segmentation dataset, and an average dice similarity coefficient of 0.9

In this paper, we propose a scalable variational inference algorithm for log-supermodular models, which are a class of probabilistic graphical models that have gained popularity in recent years due to their ability to model complex dependencies and relationships in data. The main challenge in inference for these models is the intractability of the normalizing constant, which makes it difficult to perform exact inference.

Existing methods for approximate inference in log-supermodular models are often limited by their ability to handle large datasets or complex models. In this paper, we introduce a novel algorithm that leverages the idea of divisive normalization to perform scalable variational inference in log-supermodular models. Our approach allows for efficient and accurate approximation of the posterior distribution, even in the presence of large datasets or complex models.

We evaluate the performance of our algorithm on several benchmark datasets and compare it to existing methods. Our results show that our algorithm outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency, making it a promising approach for large-scale inference in log-supermodular models. We also demonstrate the applicability of our algorithm to real-world tasks such as image segmentation and anomaly detection.

Our main contributions can be summarized as follows:

* We propose a scalable variational inference algorithm for log-supermodular models, which leverages the idea of divisive normalization to perform efficient and accurate approximation of the posterior distribution.
* We evaluate the performance of our algorithm on several benchmark datasets and compare it to existing methods, showing that it outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.
* We demonstrate the applicability of our algorithm to real-world tasks such as image segmentation and anomaly detection.

Overall, our paper provides a significant contribution to the field of probabilistic graphical models and inference, and paves the way for scalable inference in log-supermodular models for large-scale data analysis and machine learning applications.

In this paper, we present a novel approach for segmenting surgical tools from medical images without requiring manual annotations. Image compositing is used to combine multiple images of the surgical scene, each captured with a different imaging modality or under different conditions, into a single image that enhances the visibility and distinguishability of the tools. We propose a two-stage framework consisting of (1) image registration and fusion, followed by (2) deep learning-based instance segmentation. The first stage aligns and combines the input images using a robust registration technique, resulting in an enhanced image that highlights the spatial relationships between the tools. The second stage applies a state-of-the-art instance segmentation algorithm to identify and separate individual tools within the composite image.

Our proposed method was evaluated on a dataset of laparoscopic cholecystectomy images, where it achieved high accuracy and outperformed traditional image segmentation methods that rely on manual annotation. The use of image compositing significantly reduced the amount of annotated data required for training, while still maintaining accurate tool segmentation performance. This suggests that our approach has the potential to reduce the time and effort required for collecting and labeling large datasets, which can be a major bottleneck in developing machine learning models for computer vision tasks in medicine. Moreover, the ability to perform segmentation without manual annotations makes it possible to apply our method to scenarios where obtaining annotated data is difficult or impossible.

The main contributions of this work are:

* A novel approach for segmenting surgical tools from medical images without manual annotations, leveraging image compositing and deep learning techniques.
* A two-stage framework combining image registration and fusion with instance segmentation, tailored specifically to the challenges of surgical tool segmentation.
* Evaluation of the proposed method on a real-world dataset, demonstrating its effectiveness and advantages over traditional approaches relying on manual annotations.

This research paves the way for further advancements in computer vision and machine learning applications in healthcare, particularly in minimally invasive surgery, where tool segmentation can enable various augmented reality and robotics-assisted procedures.

In medical imaging, accurate segmentation of anatomical structures is crucial for diagnosis and treatment planning. However, obtaining high-quality annotations for training machine learning models can be time-consuming and expensive, particularly when expert annotators may have varying interpretations of the same image data. This study addresses this challenge by proposing a novel approach to segmentation that allows for multiple acceptable annotations, which we term "segmentation with multiple acceptable annotations" (SMAA).

We apply SMAA to the problem of myocardial segmentation in contrast echocardiography, where accurate segmentation is essential for assessing cardiac function and identifying diseases such as heart failure. Our approach leverages a deep learning model that can learn from multiple annotated datasets, each created by a different expert annotator. We evaluate the performance of SMAA using a dataset of 100 images, each annotated by three experts.

The results show that SMAA outperforms traditional single-annotation approaches, achieving a mean Dice similarity coefficient of 0.83 compared to 0.76 for the best single annotation. Additionally, SMAA reduces the variability in segmentation accuracy across annotators, indicating improved robustness to individual differences in interpretation.

Our findings demonstrate the potential of SMAA to improve the accuracy and efficiency of medical image segmentation tasks, particularly in situations where obtaining consensus among expert annotators is difficult or impossible. The proposed method has important implications for the development of automated segmentation algorithms that can be used in clinical practice, ultimately leading to better patient outcomes.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to few-shot segmentation that combines self-guided and cross-guided learning. Few-shot segmentation is a challenging task due to the limited number of training examples available for each class, which can lead to overfitting and poor generalization to unseen data. To address this challenge, we introduce a framework that leverages both self-guided and cross-guided information to improve the segmentation performance.

The proposed method consists of two main components: (1) a self-guided module that uses intra-modal similarity to learn a robust representation of each class, and (2) a cross-guided module that utilizes inter-modal correspondence to refine the segmentation results. The self-guided module encourages the model to learn a compact and discriminative feature space where samples from the same class are close together, while the cross-guided module aligns the features across different modalities to enhance the segmentation accuracy.

We evaluate our framework on several benchmark datasets, including PASCAL VOC and Cityscapes, and demonstrate its superiority compared to state-of-the-art few-shot segmentation methods. Our experiments show that the combination of self-guided and cross-guided learning leads to improved performance in terms of segmentation accuracy and robustness to variations in the input data. We also conduct an ablation study to analyze the contribution of each component and provide insights into the working mechanism of our framework.

Our work has important implications for real-world applications where labeled data is scarce or difficult to obtain. By enabling accurate segmentation with fewer annotations, our approach has the potential to reduce the cost and increase the efficiency of segmentation tasks in various domains such as medical imaging, autonomous driving, and robotics.

In this paper, we investigate the $L^2$ well-posedness of boundary value problems for parabolic systems with measurable coefficients. We consider a class of nonlinear parabolic systems with coefficients that are merely measurable, and we establish the existence and uniqueness of solutions in the $L^2$ sense. Our approach relies on a combination of energy methods, probabilistic techniques, and the theory of linear partial differential equations.

We first prove the existence of a solution by approximating the system using a sequence of smooth, compactly supported functions and then passing to the limit. We then show that the solution is unique by using a duality argument and the fact that the solution satisfies a certain energy inequality.

Our main result provides a sufficient condition for the $L^2$ well-posedness of the system, which involves a combination of the Lipschitz continuity of the coefficients and their $L^p$ integrability. We also provide examples of systems that satisfy this condition and discuss the sharpness of our result.

Our work extends previous results in the literature, which have focused on the case of smooth coefficients, and provides a new perspective on the well-posedness of parabolic systems with measurable coefficients. The $L^2$ well-posedness of such systems is a fundamental problem in partial differential equations, and our results have important implications for the study of nonlinear parabolic systems in general.

In addition, our methods and techniques can be applied to a wide range of problems in calculus of variations, evolutionary equations, and other areas of mathematics and physics, where the study of well-posedness and regularity of solutions is a central concern.

Overall, our paper provides a significant contribution to the study of parabolic systems with measurable coefficients, and it opens up new avenues for research in this area.

This paper explores the question of whether image super-resolution (ISR) is helpful for other vision tasks. ISR is a technique that aims to enhance the resolution of low-quality images by exploiting information from neighboring pixels or frames. While ISR has been shown to improve image quality, its impact on downstream vision tasks remains unclear.

To investigate this question, we conducted a comprehensive evaluation of ISR's effectiveness in supporting various computer vision applications, including object detection, facial recognition, and visual tracking. We considered several state-of-the-art ISR algorithms and evaluated their performance on benchmark datasets.

Our results demonstrate that ISR can indeed be beneficial for certain vision tasks, particularly those that rely on spatial details, such as object detection and facial recognition. However, the improvement offered by ISR varies across different task types and dataset conditions. Specifically, we found that ISR exhibits limited benefits when applied to tasks that require temporal information, like visual tracking.

We also investigated the role of different ISR architectures and loss functions in improving downstream vision tasks. Our findings suggest that ISR models employing progressive upsampling and incorporating semantic information into the restoration process tend to perform better overall. Furthermore, we observed that combining ISR with domain adaptation techniques can significantly enhance performance in some cases.

This study provides valuable insights into the potential benefits and limitations of utilizing ISR for supporting various computer vision applications. The findings have important implications for developers aiming to leverage ISR in real-world scenarios where image quality plays a crucial role. Future research directions include exploring deeper integration between ISR and downstream vision tasks, as well as examining the applicability of ISR to other image modalities beyond RGB.

In this paper, we introduce the concept of quasi-power law ensembles, which are probability distributions that exhibit a power law tail but have a finite expected value. We explore the properties and characteristics of these ensembles and show that they can be used to model phenomena that are typically described by power laws, but with the added benefit of being computationally tractable. We also discuss the relationship between quasi-power law ensembles and other heavy-tailed distributions, such as the Pareto distribution, and provide examples of applications where quasi-power law ensembles may be useful, such as in image and audio compression, and in modeling the distribution of income or wealth. Finally, we derive an algorithm for generating samples from a quasi-power law ensemble, which makes it possible to simulate and analyze these distributions in practice. Our work has important implications for the study of heavy-tailed distributions and their applications in a wide range of fields.

In this paper, we propose a new challenge called VisDA: The Visual Domain Adaptation Challenge. The goal of VisDA is to evaluate the ability of machine learning models to adapt to changes in the visual domain, specifically when encountering unseen data from different domains or environments.

Domain adaptation has become an increasingly important research area due to its potential applications in various fields such as computer vision, robotics, and autonomous driving. However, most existing work focuses on adapting models to new environments within the same domain (e.g., adapting a model trained on synthetic images to real-world images). There is a lack of benchmarks and challenges that test a model's ability to generalize across multiple domains with diverse visual styles, modalities, and formats.

To address this gap, we introduce VisDA, which consists of several tasks that require participants to develop models that can adapt to various visual domain shifts. These tasks include image classification, object detection, segmentation, and generation, each with their own set of source and target datasets representing different domains. We also provide a comprehensive evaluation framework to measure the performance of participating models under different domain shift scenarios.

The paper presents details of the VisDA challenge, including dataset descriptions, task definitions, evaluation metrics, and submission guidelines. We invite researchers and practitioners from academia and industry to participate in VisDA and contribute solutions that advance the state-of-the-art in visual domain adaptation. The challenge will be hosted annually, with results published in a dedicated proceedings volume at top AI conferences. By fostering a community-driven effort towards solving this critical problem, we envision VisDA to play a vital role in catalyzing innovations that enable more robust and reliable AI systems for real-world applications.

This paper presents a novel approach for separating intensity and warping effects in image registration. The proposed method, dubbed Most Likely Separation (MLS), leverages a probabilistic framework to disentangle the underlying factors that contribute to image misalignment. By modeling the intensity variation and warping effects as independent random processes, MLS enables their separation, leading to improved accuracy in registering images.

Experiments conducted on various datasets demonstrate the superior performance of MLS compared to state-of-the-art methods, particularly when dealing with large deformations or complex scenes. Additionally, we show that MLS can be used for tasks beyond image registration, such as optical flow estimation and visual odometry.

The key contribution of this work is the introduction of a principled way to separate intensity and warping effects, which has important implications for a wide range of computer vision applications. Our results provide strong evidence that accounting for these factors separately leads to more accurate and robust performance.

This paper provides a detailed description of the MLS algorithm, its mathematical formulation, and an extensive evaluation of its performance. We also discuss the limitations and potential extensions of our approach, paving the way for future research in this area. Overall, Most Likely Separation of Intensity and Warping Effects in Image Registration represents a significant step forward in the field of image registration and related areas.
