The abstract of an academic paper should provide a concise summary of the paper's main contributions, methods, and findings. Here's an example of an abstract for a paper titled "Transfinite Adams representability":

In this paper, we explore the concept of transfinite Adams representability, a generalization of the classical Adams representability theorem that allows for the representation of infinite groups. We develop a new framework for understanding the relationship between group cohomology and the representations of infinite groups, and use this framework to establish the transfinite Adams representability of a class of infinite groups. Our approach relies on a novel combination of techniques from algebraic topology, homological algebra, and category theory, and provides a unified perspective on a range of previously disparate results in the literature. We demonstrate the applicability of our methods by computing the transfinite Adams representations of several classes of infinite groups, including the dyadic sobriety groups and the groups of piecewise-linear homeomorphisms of the real line. Our results have important implications for the study of infinite group theory and its connections to other areas of mathematics, such as algebraic K-theory and the homology of infinite groups.

Abstract:

Background: Foreground object detection is a fundamental task in computer vision that involves identifying objects or regions of interest in an image or video sequence. While supervised learning approaches have shown promising results, they require annotated data, which can be time-consuming and expensive to obtain.

Objective: In this paper, we propose an unsupervised learning approach for foreground object detection, which does not rely on annotated data. Our goal is to develop a method that can learn to detect foreground objects without any prior knowledge of the object categories or their locations.

Methodology: We introduce a novel deep neural network architecture that leverages the concept of self-supervision to learn a representation of the foreground objects. The network consists of two components: a background subtraction module and a clustering module. The background subtraction module separates the input video frames into background and foreground layers, while the clustering module groups pixels in the foreground layer into distinct clusters. We use a self-supervised loss function that encourages the network to produce similar embeddings for pixels belonging to the same cluster and dissimilar embeddings for pixels belonging to different clusters.

Results: We evaluate our approach on several publicly available datasets, including VideoPose, COCO-VIDEO, and YouTube-VOS. Our experiments show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art unsupervised foreground object detection methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in real-world scenarios, such as detecting pedestrians in surveillance videos.

Conclusion: This paper presents an effective unsupervised learning approach for foreground object detection. Our method has important implications for various applications, including autonomous driving, surveillance, and robotics, where object detection must be performed in real-time without manual annotation. Future work includes further improving the accuracy and robustness of our approach, as well as exploring new applications in various domains.

In this paper, we present a novel approach for maximum likelihood reconstruction of neurons from noisy and incomplete data using Hidden Markov Models (HMMs). The proposed method is specifically designed to address the challenges of reconstructing neurons from large-scale calcium imaging data, where the observed signals are often noisy and incomplete.

Existing methods for neuron reconstruction rely on manual segmentation or simple thresholding techniques, which can be time-consuming and prone to errors. In contrast, our HMM-based approach uses a probabilistic framework to infer the most likely neuron structure given the observed data. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method using simulated and real data, and show that it outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.

Our approach consists of two main components: a generative model that describes the probability distribution of the observed data given the neuron structure, and an inference algorithm that finds the most likely neuron structure given the observed data. The generative model is based on a HMM, which captures the temporal dynamics of the neuron's activity patterns. The inference algorithm uses a variant of the Expectation-Maximization algorithm to find the maximum likelihood estimate of the neuron structure.

We evaluate our method using a variety of simulations and real-world data sets. Our results show that our method can accurately reconstruct neurons from noisy and incomplete data, and outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency. We also demonstrate the versatility of our approach by applying it to different types of neurons and imaging modalities.

Overall, our paper presents a powerful and flexible method for maximum likelihood reconstruction of neurons from large-scale calcium imaging data. The proposed method has important implications for the analysis of neural activity and the understanding of neural circuits, and could potentially be used to improve the accuracy and efficiency of neural imaging techniques in a variety of fields.

This paper explores the use of graph entropies in texture segmentation of images. Texture segmentation is a fundamental task in computer vision that involves dividing an image into regions of similar texture. Graph entropies, which capture the entropy of a graph representation of the image, have shown promising results in image segmentation tasks. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that utilizes graph entropies to segment images into regions of similar texture.

Our approach begins with converting the image into a graph, where each pixel is represented by a node, and edges are added between pixels that are similar in intensity or color. We then calculate the graph entropy of the resulting graph, which provides a measure of the randomness or disorder of the graph. We use the graph entropy to compute a threshold value that separates the graph into regions of similar texture.

We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets, including the Brodatz texture dataset, the UIUC texture dataset, and the KTH-TIPSTER texture dataset. Our experiments show that our approach outperforms traditional texture segmentation methods, such as gray-level co-occurrence matrices and local Binary Patterns, in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency.

We also perform a series of experiments to analyze the effect of different parameters on the performance of our approach. Our results show that the choice of graph structure and the size of the neighborhood have a significant impact on the segmentation performance. We also demonstrate that our approach is robust to noise and can handle images with varying levels of texture complexity.

Our work provides a new perspective on texture segmentation and demonstrates the potential of graph entropies in this task. The proposed approach has important applications in various fields such as object recognition, image compression, and robot vision. Future work includes exploring other graph-based features and incorporating higher-level features to further improve the segmentation performance.

CASSOD-Net: Cascaded and Separable Structures of Dilated Convolution for Embedded Vision Systems and Applications

In this paper, we propose a novel deep neural network architecture called CASSOD-Net, designed specifically for embedded vision systems and applications. CASSOD-Net stands for Cascaded and Separable Structures of Dilated Convolution, which highlights its unique design that combines both cascaded and separable convolutional structures with dilated convolutions.

The proposed CASSOD-Net architecture aims to address the computational efficiency and accuracy requirements of embedded vision systems, which are often limited by computational resources and power consumption. By employing dilated convolutions, CASSOD-Net increases the receptive field of the network without augmenting the number of parameters, thereby improving feature capture and representation.

The cascaded structure in CASSOD-Net enables the network to learn hierarchical representations, while the separable structure reduces the computational cost and memory usage. This is particularly important in embedded systems, where resources are limited and optimization is crucial.

Experiments conducted on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CASSOD-Net outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of accuracy and efficiency. Specifically, CASSOD-Net achieves better performance than existing models on object detection, semantic segmentation, and image classification tasks, while requiring fewer parameters and computations.

The proposed architecture is also evaluated on real-world embedded platforms, showing improved performance compared to existing models in terms of energy efficiency and speed. This makes CASSOD-Net an attractive solution for a wide range of applications, such as autonomous driving, surveillance, robotics, and IoT devices.

In summary, CASSOD-Net presents a novel and efficient deep neural network architecture that leverages dilated convolutions, cascaded and separable structures, and careful design choices to achieve state-of-the-art performance in embedded vision systems and applications. Its computational efficiency, accuracy, and adaptability make it an ideal solution for resource-constrained devices and applications.

In this paper, we introduce a new class of graphs called Ordered Exchange Graphs (OEGs), which are derived from exchangeable random graph models. OEGs are distinguished by their unique combination of properties: they have a fixed number of vertices, each vertex has a fixed degree, and the edges are assigned in a particular order.

We show that OEGs exhibit several interesting structural properties, including the existence of large cliques, a power-law distribution of degrees, and high clustering coefficients. Additionally, we explore the connectivity properties of OEGs and demonstrate that they are highly connected, with any two vertices being connected by a path of length at most 3.

Furthermore, we investigate the probabilistic properties of OEGs, including the probability of edge exchange between pairs of vertices, and show that the graphs exhibit a high level of edge stability. We also study the relationship between OEGs and other classes of random graphs, such as the classical Erdos-Renyi model, and demonstrate that OEGs exhibit a distinctive phase transition phenomenon.

The paper concludes with an exploration of potential applications of OEGs, including their use in social network analysis and image segmentation tasks. Our findings provide evidence that OEGs offer a valuable framework for understanding complex systems where structure and order play important roles.

In this paper, we present a novel approach for generating complex breathers in the Korteweg-de Vries (KdV) equation through isospectral deformation of the free particle system. By exploiting the connection between the KdV equation and the spectral problem of the one-dimensional Schrdinger equation, we show that the free particle can be used as a seed solution to generate a wide range of complex breathers with arbitrary amplitude and velocity.

Using the isospectral deformation method, we demonstrate that the free particle solution can be deformed into a family of nonlinear breathers with distinct dynamical behaviors, including periodic, quasi-periodic, and chaotic motion. We show that these breathers exhibit a rich variety of structures, including single-layer, multi-layer, and vortex-like patterns, and that they can be controlled by adjusting the parameters of the deformation.

Our results provide a new and efficient way to generate complex breathers in the KdV equation, which is of great interest in various fields, such as nonlinear optics, fluid dynamics, and plasma physics. The isospectral deformation method presented here offers a powerful tool for exploring the nonlinear dynamics of the KdV equation and has the potential to be applied to other nonlinear systems as well.

The paper is organized as follows: In section 1, we introduce the KdV equation and its connection to the one-dimensional Schrdinger equation. In section 2, we review the isospectral deformation method and its application to the free particle system. In section 3, we present the main results of the paper, including the generation of complex breathers through isospectral deformation and their dynamical behaviors. Finally, in section 4, we conclude with a discussion of the results and their implications, as well as suggestions for future research directions.

In this paper, we explore the connection between Brunet-Derrida particle systems, free boundary problems, and Wiener-Hopf equations. We first introduce the concept of Brunet-Derrida particle systems, which are stochastic processes that describe the evolution of a collection of particles that interact with each other through a nonlinear potential. We then discuss the relationship between these systems and free boundary problems, which are mathematical models used to study the behavior of physical systems with boundaries that are not fixed in advance.

We show how certain types of free boundary problems can be reformulated as Wiener-Hopf equations, which are partial differential equations that involve the Fourier transform. Using this approach, we demonstrate how solutions to the Wiener-Hopf equations can be used to construct solutions to the original free boundary problem. Our results provide new insights into the behavior of Brunet-Derrida particle systems and their connections to various areas of mathematics and physics.

In particular, we focus on the case where the interaction potential is given by the Newtonian potential, which leads to a class of problems known as the "gravitational" Brunet-Derrida model. For this case, we prove the existence and uniqueness of solutions to the associated Wiener-Hopf equation, and use these solutions to obtain bounds on the long-time behavior of the particle system. Our analysis reveals a rich variety of behaviors, including phase transitions and self-organization phenomena, which are of interest both from a theoretical perspective and for their potential applications in fields such as materials science and biology.

Overall, our work provides a novel perspective on the relationship between Brunet-Derrida particle systems, free boundary problems, and Wiener-Hopf equations, and demonstrates the power of using techniques from probability theory and statistical mechanics to tackle challenging problems in mathematical physics.

The abstract of the paper "Stability and Monotonicity for Some Discretizations of the Biot's Model" is as follows:

In this paper, we investigate the stability and monotonicity properties of several discretizations of the Biot's model, which is a partial differential equation that describes the dynamics of a viscoelastic solid. We consider a variety of discretization methods, including finite difference, finite element, and spectral methods, and analyze their stability and monotonicity properties.

Our results show that the stability and monotonicity properties of the discretizations depend on the specific method used and the choices of the discretization parameters. In particular, we find that some discretizations are stable and monotone, while others are not. We also identify the conditions under which the discretizations exhibit these properties and provide numerical examples to illustrate our findings.

Our analysis has important implications for the numerical simulation of viscoelastic solids, as it suggests that careful choice of discretization method and parameters is necessary to ensure accurate and reliable results. The stability and monotonicity properties of the discretizations can be used as a guide in selecting the most appropriate method for a given problem and in validating the results of numerical simulations.

Overall, this paper contributes to the understanding of the numerical analysis of partial differential equations and its application to the study of viscoelastic solids. The results provide a theoretical foundation for the development of accurate and efficient numerical methods for simulating the behavior of these materials, which are important in a wide range of engineering and scientific applications.

In this paper, we investigate the transmission of electromagnetic waves through a subwavelength nano-hole in a two-dimensional plasmonic layer. Using a numerical simulation approach, we examine the effects of various parameters such as hole size, thickness of the plasmonic layer, and incident angle on the transmission behavior. Our results show that the transmission exhibits strong dependence on these parameters, with significant enhancement of transmission amplitudes observed for certain resonant conditions. We also find that the transmission behavior can be tailored by adjusting the parameters, allowing for control over the propagation of electromagnetic waves through the nano-hole. Our findings have important implications for the development of plasmonic devices and provide a new avenue for manipulating electromagnetic waves at the nanoscale.

In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning model called Feature Fusion Encoder-Decoder Network (FFEDN) for automatic liver lesion segmentation in computed tomography (CT) images. The FFEDN combines the strengths of both encoder-decoder and feature fusion architectures to improve the accuracy and efficiency of liver lesion segmentation.

The proposed FFEDN consists of three main components: (1) a multi-scale feature extraction module that extracts features from CT images at multiple scales, (2) a spatial attention module that fuses the extracted features to enhance the representation of the input image, and (3) a decoder network that up-samples the fused features to generate the final segmentation mask.

We evaluated the performance of FFEDN on a dataset of 100 CT images with various types of liver lesions. Experimental results show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency. Specifically, FFEDN achieves an average Dice similarity coefficient of 95.6% and a mean absolute error of 1.7%, while maintaining a processing speed of 30 frames per second.

Our contributions can be summarized as follows: (1) we introduce a novel deep learning architecture that combines the strengths of encoder-decoder and feature fusion models for liver lesion segmentation, (2) we design a multi-scale feature extraction module to capture contextual information at different levels, and (3) we propose a spatial attention mechanism to selectively focus on the most relevant regions of the input image.

The proposed FFEDN has important implications for clinical applications, where accurate and efficient liver lesion segmentation is critical for diagnosis and treatment planning. Our approach has the potential to improve the accuracy and efficiency of liver lesion segmentation, and may ultimately contribute to better patient outcomes.

In this paper, we explore the concept of weakly supervised medical image segmentation, where the training data is only partially annotated. We propose a novel approach that leverages extreme learning theory to improve the accuracy of segmentation models in this setting. Our method uses a combination of extreme learning theory and deep neural networks to learn a robust representation of the image data that can be used for accurate segmentation. We evaluate our approach on several medical image datasets and show that it outperforms traditional weakly supervised segmentation methods. Our results demonstrate the potential of using extreme learning theory in medical image segmentation, and highlight the advantages of our approach in terms of accuracy and efficiency. We also discuss the limitations of our method and future directions for research in this area.

In this paper, we continue our study of lifting representations of finite reductive groups, which was initiated in our previous work. Specifically, we focus on explicit conorms, which are a fundamental tool in the study of representation theory and have numerous applications in geometry, combinatorics, and computer science.

Our main result is the construction of an algorithm that computes explicit conorms for arbitrary finite reductive groups. This algorithm is based on a novel combination of geometric and algebraic techniques, including the use of equivariant cohomology theories and the study of Schubert calculus. We demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our algorithm through several examples and applications, including the computation of conorms for symmetric and alternating groups, as well as the study of representation varieties and quiver Grassmannians.

In addition to our computational results, we also provide a theoretical analysis of the structure of conorms for finite reductive groups, including their relationship to other important invariants such as character values and decomposition numbers. Our work provides new insights into the nature of these invariants and their interplay with representation theory, and it opens up new directions for future research in this area.

Overall, our paper represents a significant contribution to the field of representation theory and its connections to geometry, algebra, and computing. It provides both practical tools and theoretical foundations for understanding the representation theory of finite reductive groups, and it paves the way for further advances in this rich and vibrant area of mathematics.

In this paper, we present a generalization of the classical Whitney formula for broken circuits in graphic matroids to the context of ambigraphs and matroids. The Whitney formula provides a combinatorial interpretation for the number of spanning trees in a graph, and has been instrumental in the study of graph theory and network analysis. Our generalized formula extends this result to ambigraphs, which are a natural generalization of graphs that allow for multiple edges between pairs of vertices, and matroids, which are a more abstract representation of independence systems. We demonstrate the versatility and power of our formula by applying it to various examples and deriving new results in both graph theory and matroid theory. Specifically, we show how our formula can be used to compute the number of spanning trees in certain classes of graphs and matroids, and provide bounds on the number of connected components in random graphs and matroids. Our work deepens the connection between graph theory, matroid theory, and algebraic combinatorics, and opens up new avenues for research in these fields.

This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the UK web space, focusing specifically on the online presence of British universities over the past fifteen years. Through a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods, including web scraping, content analysis, and case studies, we investigate the evolution of university websites, their current state, and future trends. Our findings reveal significant changes in the design, functionality, and content of university websites, reflecting shifts in higher education policies, technological advancements, and changing user expectations. We identify key drivers of change, such as the rise of digital marketing, e-learning, and research dissemination, and examine how universities have adapted to these drivers. The study also highlights challenges faced by universities in maintaining an effective online presence, including issues related to information architecture, accessibility, and brand consistency. Our analysis provides valuable insights for university administrators, policymakers, and web developers seeking to enhance the online profile of their institutions and improve the digital experience for students, staff, and external stakeholders.

Abstract:

Oligomer formation is a common phenomenon in biological systems, wherein proteins or other molecules come together to form larger complexes. While oligomers play important roles in various cellular processes, their excessive formation can also cause cell damage and contribute to diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and cancer. However, the underlying mechanisms of how oligomer formation leads to cell damage remain poorly understood. In this study, we develop a kinetic model that describes the process of oligomer formation and its impact on cell damage. Our model incorporates key factors such as protein concentration, aggregation rate, and the presence of membrane-bound particles, and simulates the dynamics of oligomer formation over time. We show that the formation of stable oligomers can indeed cause cell damage by disrupting normal cellular functions, and that the extent of damage increases with oligomer size and duration of exposure. Our results provide new insights into the mechanisms of cell damage caused by oligomer formation, and suggest potential therapeutic targets for diseases characterized by protein misfolding and aggregation.

In this paper, the authors propose a novel approach for fusing labels from multiple atlases in the context of cardiac magnetic resonance (MR) imaging. The proposed method, called Neural Multi-Atlas Label Fusion (NMALF), leverages recent advances in deep learning to combine the strengths of multiple atlases and improve the accuracy of label fusion.

Existing label fusion methods suffer from several limitations, including the need for explicit correspondence between atlas images, the difficulty in handling non-rigid deformations, and the reliance on hand-crafted features. NMALF addresses these limitations by using a neural network to learn a joint representation of the atlas images and the target image, which enables the fusion of labels from multiple atlases in a way that is robust to non-rigid deformations and does not require explicit correspondence.

The proposed method consists of two main components: a shared encoder network that maps the atlas images and the target image to a common space, and a label fusion network that combines the encoded atlas images and the target image to produce a fused label map. The shared encoder network is trained using a novel loss function that encourages the network to learn a joint representation that is discriminative for label fusion. The label fusion network is trained using a combination of dice loss and mean squared error loss.

The authors evaluate NMALF on a dataset of cardiac MR images and compare it to several state-of-the-art label fusion methods. The results show that NMALF outperforms the compared methods in terms of label fusion accuracy, demonstrating its ability to effectively combine the strengths of multiple atlases. Additionally, the authors perform an ablation study to analyze the contribution of the shared encoder network and the label fusion network to the performance of NMALF, providing insights into the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

Overall, this paper makes an important contribution to the field of medical image analysis by proposing a novel deep learning-based approach for fusing labels from multiple atlases in the context of cardiac MR imaging. The proposed method has the potential to improve the accuracy and efficiency of label fusion in various medical image analysis tasks,

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to polyp segmentation using deep ensembles based on stochastic activation selection. Colon polyps are abnormal growths on the colon wall that can potentially develop into cancerous tumors, and accurate segmentation of these polyps from computed tomography (CT) scans is crucial for early detection and treatment.

Existing approaches to polyp segmentation have limitations in terms of accuracy and efficiency, particularly when dealing with large and complex polyps. To address these challenges, we introduce a deep learning-based method that combines the strengths of ensemble learning and stochastic activation selection. Our proposed method consists of multiple deep neural networks with different architectures and hyperparameters, each trained on a subset of the dataset. The outputs from these networks are combined using a novel fusion strategy that selects the most relevant activations from each network.

We evaluate our method on a benchmark dataset of CT scans and compare it to state-of-the-art methods. Our results show that our proposed method outperforms existing approaches in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency. We also perform a series of ablation studies to analyze the effectiveness of different components of our method and demonstrate its robustness to various parameter settings.

Our main contributions include:

* A novel deep ensemble learning framework for polyp segmentation that leverages stochastic activation selection to improve accuracy and efficiency.
* A new fusion strategy that selectively combines the most informative activations from multiple deep neural networks, leading to improved performance and reduced computational cost.
* An extensive evaluation of our method on a benchmark dataset, demonstrating its superiority over existing approaches and providing insights into the optimal design choices for polyp segmentation systems.

Overall, our work has important implications for the development of accurate and efficient polyp segmentation systems, which can help improve the early detection and treatment of colorectal cancer.

In this paper, we present a novel methodology, referred to as $\mathcal{C}-$IBI, for deriving coarse-grained models of complex fluid systems. This approach targets cumulative coordination within an iterative protocol, leveraging the concept of inherent bias improvement (IBI) to simultaneously capture intrinsic correlations and hierarchy in the system. We demonstrate the efficacy of $\mathcal{C}-$IBI using various multi-component fluidic systems, showcasing its ability to provide accurate predictions of macroscopic properties while significantly reducing computational cost compared to molecular simulations. Our results indicate that $\mathcal{C)-}$IBI enhanced understanding of non-trivial dynamical behaviors in these systems, including phase separation and wetting phenomena, which are challenging to model accurately at finer scales. The presented method has far-reaching implications for efficient simulations and rational design of complex materials where microscopic details may not be directly relevant or computationally tractable.

The abstract of the paper "PISA: Pixelwise Image Saliency by Aggregating Complementary Appearance Contrast Measures with Edge-Preserving Coherence" could be something like this:

This paper introduces PISA, a novel method for calculating pixel-level image saliency. PISA combines different appearance contrast measures with edge-preserving coherence to produce a more accurate and robust saliency map. Existing saliency models tend to rely on a single contrast mechanism, which can result in reduced performance in certain scenarios. PISA, on the other hand, aggregates multiple contrast measures that complement each other, enhancing the overall performance. Additionally, the proposed method incorporates edge-preserving coherence to ensure that the resulting saliency map is consistent with the image's edges and boundaries, further improving its accuracy.

The authors evaluate PISA on several datasets and compare it to state-of-the-art saliency models. The results show that PISA outperforms other models in terms of accuracy and robustness, particularly in scenarios with complex backgrounds, low-contrast objects, or high-frequency noise. Furthermore, the paper presents a detailed analysis of the effects of different contrast measures and coherence factors on the overall performance, providing insights into the strengths and limitations of various design choices.

The abstract should provide a clear and concise summary of the main contributions and key findings of the paper, giving readers a sense of the novelty and significance of the proposed method.

In disease mapping studies, predictive p-values are essential for evaluating the significance of spatial clusters and identifying areas of high disease risk. However, estimating these p-values using traditional methods can be computationally expensive, particularly when working with large datasets or complex models. To address this challenge, we propose a novel approach called integrated importance sampling (IIS), which combines the strengths of importance sampling and Gaussian process models to estimate cross-validatory predictive p-values efficiently.

In this paper, we develop an IIS algorithm that integrates the estimation of predictive p-values within the model fitting process, allowing for fast and accurate inference. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method using extensive simulations and real-data applications in disease mapping. Our results show that IIS significantly reduces computational costs compared to existing methods while maintaining accuracy, making it particularly suitable for large-scale surveillance data.

Moreover, we explore the properties of the proposed method and provide insights into its relationship with other approaches in the literature. Our findings highlight the potential of IIS as a general tool for Bayesian model selection and model averaging in disease mapping and beyond. This study contributes to the development of efficient algorithms for uncertainty quantification in computational biology and epidemiology, ultimately supporting informed decision-making in public health policy and interventions.

In this paper, we present a novel approach for semantic segmentation of video sequences using Convolutional LSTMs (ConvLSTMs). Semantic segmentation aims to assign a class label to each pixel in an image, indicating the object or material it belongs to. In video sequences, this task is particularly challenging due to the temporal dynamics of the visual content and the need to capture both short-term and long-term dependencies.

To address this challenge, we propose a deep neural network architecture that combines the strengths of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. Our approach uses ConvLSTMs to learn both spatial and temporal features from raw video frames, and then employs a segmentation module to predict the class label for each pixel in each frame.

We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets, including Cityscapes, CamVid, and Youtube-VOS. The results show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency. Specifically, we achieve an mIoU of 75.1% on Cityscapes and 83.2% on CamVid, while maintaining a high frame rate of 30 fps.

Our key contributions can be summarized as follows:

* We propose a novel architecture that combines ConvLSTMs and a segmentation module for semantic segmentation of video sequences.
* We introduce a new training strategy that leverages transfer learning and data augmentation to improve the generalization of our model.
* We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in both accuracy and efficiency.

Overall, our work has important implications for a wide range of applications, including autonomous driving, robotics, and video surveillance.

Flood-Filling Networks: A Novel Approach to Efficient Image Segmentation

Image segmentation is a fundamental task in computer vision that involves dividing an image into its constituent parts or objects. It is a key step in various applications such as object recognition, tracking, and scene understanding. However, segmenting images efficiently and accurately remains a challenging problem, especially in the presence of complex objects or scenes with varying illumination conditions.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to image segmentation called Flood-Filling Networks (FFNs). The basic idea behind FFNs is to represent an image as a graph, where each pixel is a node, and the edges connect pixels that are similar in intensity or color. The nodes are then hierarchically grouped into clusters using a novel flood-filling algorithm, which iteratively expands the clusters by propagating the information through the graph. The resulting segmentation is efficient, accurate, and robust to varying illumination conditions.

We evaluate the performance of FFNs on several benchmark datasets, including synthetic and real-world images, and compare it with state-of-the-art segmentation methods. The results show that FFNs outperform other methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency. In addition, we demonstrate the versatility of FFNs by applying them to various computer vision tasks such as object recognition, tracking, and scene understanding.

The main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows:

* We propose a novel approach to image segmentation called Flood-Filling Networks (FFNs) that represents an image as a graph and uses a flood-filling algorithm to hierarchically group pixels into clusters.
* We demonstrate the efficiency and accuracy of FFNs on several benchmark datasets and show that they outperform state-of-the-art segmentation methods.
* We explore the versatility of FFNs by applying them to various computer vision tasks such as object recognition, tracking, and scene understanding.

Overall, this paper presents a significant advance in image segmentation technology, and the proposed Flood-Filling Networks have the potential to become a new standard in the field.

In this paper, we propose a new challenge and benchmark dataset called VisDA (Visual Domain Adaptation) to evaluate the performance of domain adaptation methods in computer vision tasks. Existing domain adaptation benchmarks focus mainly on text classification and neglect the unique challenges posed by visual data. VisDA addresses this gap by providing a diverse set of image datasets from various domains, including object recognition, scene understanding, and medical imaging.

The VisDA challenge consists of multiple task-specific sub-challenges, each with its own evaluation metric. These sub-challenges are designed to test different aspects of domain adaptation, such as adaptability to new classes, styles, and domains. We also provide a set of baseline models that utilize popular domain adaptation techniques, allowing participants to compare their approaches against established methods.

To further facilitate research in this area, we will host an annual competition where participants can submit their adapted models and compete against others. The winner will be selected based on their performance on a held-out test set.

We believe that VisDA will serve as a valuable resource for researchers working on domain adaptation in computer vision, encouraging them to develop more effective and robust methods that can handle diverse real-world scenarios.

In this paper, we present YouTube-VOS, a large-scale video object segmentation benchmark that aims to evaluate the performance of video object segmentation (VOS) algorithms on a diverse set of videos from YouTube. The benchmark consists of 4000 video clips, each annotated with high-quality object masks for up to 5 objects per frame. We also provide a detailed evaluation metric that measures the accuracy and efficiency of VOS algorithms.

We conduct extensive experiments on several state-of-the-art VOS algorithms and analyze their performance on different categories of objects, object sizes, and frame rates. Our results show that current VOS algorithms struggle with objects that are small, have low contrast, or are partially occluded. We also find that there is a trade-off between accuracy and efficiency, with more accurate algorithms being slower and less efficient.

YouTube-VOS provides a large-scale benchmark for the development and evaluation of VOS algorithms, which is much needed in the research community. It provides a platform for researchers to test and compare their algorithms on a diverse set of videos and objects, and helps to drive the development of more accurate and efficient VOS algorithms. The benchmark is available for public download and is expected to be a valuable resource for researchers and practitioners working in the field of computer vision and video processing.

This paper presents a novel approach to constructing set-valued fundamental diagrams (SFDs) for second-order traffic models. SFDs are widely used in transportation research to study the behavior of traffic flow and to calibrate traffic simulation models. However, their construction is often based on simplifying assumptions and lacks a rigorous mathematical foundation. In this paper, we propose a new method that uses jamiton solutions - a type of nonlinear wave solution that can capture the formation of stop-and-go waves in traffic flow - to construct SFDs. We show that these jamiton solutions can be used to generate a family of feasible and physically meaningful SFDs that can capture a wide range of traffic phenomena, including shockwaves, rarefaction fans, and stop-and-go waves. The proposed method provides a more realistic representation of traffic flow than traditional methods and can help improve the accuracy of traffic simulations and modeling. Moreover, it offers a promising way to estimate model parameters from empirical data, which can help to reduce the uncertainty in traffic predictions. Our results have important implications for traffic engineering and management, as they provide a better understanding of the dynamics of traffic flow and can help to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion.

Background:
Skin lesion segmentation is a crucial step in diagnosing and treating skin diseases. Deep learning techniques have shown promising results in this task, but they require high-quality annotated data for training. However, obtaining accurate annotations can be time-consuming and expensive, especially when dealing with noisy or low-quality images. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages noisy annotations to train deep neural networks for skin lesion segmentation.

Methodology:
We introduce a new dataset of skin lesion images with noisy annotations, which contain various types of errors such as missing boundaries, incorrect labels, and artifacts. We then propose a two-stage framework to learn from these noisy annotations. The first stage involves training a convolutional neural network (CNN) on the noisy annotations to generate an initial segmentation mask. The second stage consists of a conditional random field (CRF) refinement module that incorporates both image intensity information and boundary cues to improve the segmentation accuracy.

Results:
Our experiments show that our proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art methods trained on clean datasets, while also being robust to different types of noise in the annotations. Specifically, we achieve an average dice similarity coefficient of 0.832 on our test set, compared to 0.795 by a supervised learning baseline. Moreover, we conduct ablation studies to analyze the effectiveness of the CRF refinement module and demonstrate its contribution to improving segmentation accuracy.

Conclusion:
In this paper, we presented a novel approach for skin lesion segmentation using noisy annotations. Our proposed method combines a CNN with a CRF refinement module to leverage noisy annotations for training, leading to improved segmentation performance and robustness to annotation noise. This work has important implications for developing practical and cost-effective solutions for skin disease diagnosis, where high-quality annotated data may not always be available.

In this paper, we present a coalgebraic approach to fair simulation for nondeterministic and probabilistic Bchi automata. These automata are widely used in formal verification and synthesis to model and analyze systems with both deterministic and nondeterministic behavior. However, their simulation is challenging, especially when the automata have multiple accepting states, as the standard simulation relations are not sufficient to capture the fairness properties of the system.

We propose a coalgebraic framework for fair simulation of nondeterministic and probabilistic Bchi automata, which is based on the notion of a coalgebraic logic. This logic allows us to reason about the behavior of the automata in a way that is modular, compositional, and equivariant with respect to the underlying symmetry of the system. We define a family of simulation relations that are based on the coalgebraic logic and are able to capture the fairness properties of the system.

We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach by applying it to several case studies, including a probabilistic timer automaton and a queueing system. Our results show that our coalgebraic approach is able to efficiently simulate the behavior of these systems and detect violations of fairness properties that would be difficult or impossible to detect using traditional methods.

Our work contributes to the development of a theory of fair simulation for nondeterministic and probabilistic systems, and provides a new perspective on the relationship between coalgebraic logic and simulation. It also has practical applications in the verification and synthesis of systems with fairness constraints, such as in the design of fair schedulers, resource allocation algorithms, and communication protocols.

In this paper, we explore the concept of dynamical boson stars, which are hypothetical celestial objects composed of bosons, a type of subatomic particle. We examine the properties and behavior of these objects using a combination of analytical and numerical methods, including simulations and stability analysis. Our results show that dynamical boson stars can exhibit unique features such as oscillations, fragmentation, and critical phenomena, which are not found in traditional stellar systems.

We also investigate the role of nonlinear interactions and external perturbations on the dynamics of boson stars and demonstrate how they can lead to the formation of stable configurations or collapse into black holes. Additionally, we discuss the possible astrophysical implications of our findings and suggest potential ways to detect dynamical boson stars in observation. Overall, our work provides new insights into the physics of collective behavior in many-body quantum systems and opens up avenues for further research in theoretical astronomy and cosmology.

In this paper, we revisit the traditional approach of graph construction for fast image segmentation and propose a new method that improves upon the efficiency and accuracy of existing methods. Graph-based image segmentation has been a popular approach in computer vision for its ability to model complex objects and capture subtle boundaries. However, the construction of the graph itself can be computationally expensive, limiting the scalability of the method.

Our proposed method, called FastGC, addresses this limitation by introducing a novel graph construction algorithm that is both efficient and effective. FastGC leverages a combination of spatial and intensity-based features to build a graph that captures the essential structure of the image. We also introduce a new iterative routing algorithm that enables the graph to adapt to the changing segmentation landscape, ensuring that the final segmentation is accurate and consistent.

We evaluate FastGC on several benchmark datasets and compare it to state-of-the-art segmentation methods, including both graph-based and deep learning-based approaches. Our experiments show that FastGC achieves superior segmentation accuracy and efficiency compared to existing methods, making it a promising solution for large-scale image segmentation tasks.

The main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows:

* A novel graph construction algorithm that is efficient and effective for image segmentation
* A new iterative routing algorithm that adapts the graph to the changing segmentation landscape
* State-of-the-art segmentation performance on several benchmark datasets
* A thorough evaluation of FastGC's efficiency and scalability, demonstrating its suitability for large-scale image segmentation tasks.

Overall, our work represents a significant advancement in graph-based image segmentation, and we believe that FastGC has the potential to be a valuable tool for a wide range of applications in computer vision and beyond.

In the field of artificial intelligence, description logics (DL) have emerged as a popular formalism for representing and reasoning with ontologies, which are formal representations of concepts and relationships in a domain of interest. A key aspect of DL ontologies is their ability to capture complex relationships between concepts, which can result in large and complex datasets. In this paper, we investigate the data complexity of DL ontologies, which refers to the difficulty of storing, querying, and reasoning with these ontologies.

We first provide a comprehensive overview of the data complexity of DL ontologies, including its main components and the challenges associated with managing and reasoning with large and complex ontologies. We then present a series of theoretical and empirical studies that evaluate the data complexity of DL ontologies from various perspectives, including the size and structure of the ontologies, the complexity of the relationships between concepts, and the performance of reasoning algorithms.

Our results show that the data complexity of DL ontologies can be quite high, especially for large and complex ontologies. We identify several factors that contribute to this complexity, including the number of concepts and relationships, the depth and width of the ontology, and the complexity of the relationships between concepts. We also evaluate the impact of different design choices, such as the use of abstraction and the organization of concepts, on the data complexity of DL ontologies.

Our findings have important implications for the design and implementation of DL ontologies. We propose several strategies for reducing the data complexity of DL ontologies, including the use of modular ontologies, the elimination of redundant concepts, and the use of more efficient reasoning algorithms. We also discuss the trade-offs between data complexity and other desirable properties of DL ontologies, such as expressivity and consistency.

Overall, our research provides a better understanding of the data complexity of DL ontologies and its impact on the design and implementation of these formalisms. Our findings and recommendations will be useful for researchers and practitioners who work with DL ontologies, and will help to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of these powerful tools for representing and reasoning with knowledge.

In this paper, we present a novel approach to image segmentation that leverages the concept of diversity to improve accuracy and efficiency. Traditional segmentation methods rely on hand-crafted features or deep learning models that are limited by their inability to capture the full range of variations in image data. Our proposed method, called DiverseSeg, exploits the inherent diversity present in images to learn more robust and flexible representations.

We begin by introducing a diversity-promoting regularization term into the traditional segmentation loss function. This term encourages the model to explore a wider range of feature spaces, leading to improved performance on diverse datasets. We also propose a novel optimization algorithm that adapts the regularization strength based on the similarity between the current prediction and the ground truth.

Extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach. Compared to state-of-the-art methods, DiverseSeg achieves superior performance on various metrics, including intersection over union (IoU), precision, recall, and F1-score. Additionally, we show that our method is more robust to adversarial attacks and produces more consistent results across different domains.

Our main contributions can be summarized as follows:

* We introduce a novel approach to image segmentation that leverages diversity to improve accuracy and robustness.
* We propose a diversity-promoting regularization term and an adaptive optimization algorithm to effectively explore and exploit diversity.
* Extensive experimental results demonstrate the superiority of our approach compared to state-of-the-art methods.

Overall, this paper provides a new perspective on image segmentation and highlights the importance of exploring and exploiting diversity in image data. The proposed method has significant implications for various computer vision applications, such as object detection, tracking, and scene understanding.

This paper compares and contrasts two approaches to formalizing and analyzing systems with complex behaviors: state/event-based logics and pure action-based or state-based logics. The former approach represents system behavior as a sequence of events that change the system's state, while the latter represent it as a set of actions that modify the system's state directly. We explore the advantages and limitations of each approach and discuss their applicability to different types of systems.

Our analysis reveals that state/event-based logics are more expressive and can capture subtle properties of systems that pure action-based or state-based logics cannot. However, they also suffer from the problem of non-determinism, which can make it difficult to reason about the behavior of large systems. In contrast, pure action-based or state-based logics are less expressive but offer greater clarity and determinacy in their results.

We evaluate the tradeoffs between these approaches using several case studies, including a simple ATM system and a railroad crossing. Our findings suggest that state/event-based logics are better suited for modeling systems with complex, fine-grained behavior, while pure action-based or state-based logics are more appropriate for systems where simplicity and determinacy are paramount.

Overall, this study provides insights into the strengths and weaknesses of different logical frameworks for representing and reasoning about complex systems. It highlights the importance of carefully choosing the right approach depending on the specific needs of the application domain.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach called DeepAtlas that combines image registration and segmentation using joint semi-supervised learning. Existing methods typically address these tasks separately, with image registration being performed first, followed by segmentation. However, this sequential approach can lead to suboptimal results since registration and segmentation are inherently related.

DeepAtlas addresses this limitation by introducing a new architecture that simultaneously learns both registration and segmentation in a single workflow. Our method leverages unsupervised domain adaptation techniques to minimize the need for annotated data and maximize performance. We also introduce a new loss function that enables the network to learn from both labeled and unlabored data during training.

We evaluate Deep Atlas on several publicly available datasets, including BraTS, IU-OMRON, MEDSEG, and MM-BCAD. The experimental results demonstrate that our proposed method outperform state-of-the-art approaches in terms of registration accuracy and segmentation purity. Specifically, DeepAtlas achieves an average Dice score of 93.65% across all datasets, significantly improving upon the previous state of the art. Additionally, we perform comprehensive ablation studies to analyze the effectiveness of different components of the DeepAtlas framework, providing valuable insights into how to optimize such approaches in future work. Overall, this paper presents a significant advancement in the field of medical image analysis, paving the way for more accurate and efficient registration and segmentation methods.

Abstract:

Accurate medical image segmentation is a crucial task in various medical applications, such as tumor diagnosis, organ segmentation, and disease progression modeling. However, manual segmentation is time-consuming and challenging, particularly for complex anatomical structures. In this paper, we propose DeepIGeoS, a deep interactive geodesic framework for medical image segmentation. DeepIGeoS combines the strengths of deep learning and interactive geodesic modeling to provide an efficient and accurate solution for medical image segmentation.

DeepIGeoS consists of two main components: a deep neural network (DNN) and an interactive geodesic model. The DNN is trained on a large dataset of labeled medical images to learn the underlying patterns and features. The interactive geodesic model is used to model the anatomical structures in the image and to provide an intuitive interface for user interaction.

The proposed framework is evaluated on several publicly available medical image datasets, including MRI brain tumor segmentation, CT lung nodule segmentation, and retinal vessel segmentation. The results show that DeepIGeoS outperforms traditional segmentation methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency. In addition, user studies demonstrate that DeepIGeoS is easy to use and provides accurate segmentation results with minimal user input.

DeepIGeoS has the potential to revolutionize medical image segmentation by providing an accurate, efficient, and user-friendly solution for clinicians and researchers. The proposed framework can be used for a wide range of medical applications, including disease diagnosis, treatment planning, and monitoring.

Keywords: medical image segmentation, deep learning, interactive geodesic model, tumor diagnosis, organ segmentation, disease progression modeling.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to semantic image segmentation called Auto-DeepLab, which leverages hierarchical neural architecture search (HNAS) to optimize both the encoder and decoder architectures of a deep learning model. Unlike traditional NAS methods that focus on searching for a single optimal architecture, HNAS allows for the discovery of multiple hierarchical architectures that can be combined to form a more powerful and accurate model. Our proposed method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets, including Cityscapes, PASCAL VOC, and COCO, and achieves state-of-the-art performance in comparison to other state-of-the-art segmentation models.

The key contribution of this work is the development of an efficient and effective HNAS algorithm that can simultaneously explore the space of possible encoder and decoder architectures. This is achieved through a novel combination of reinforcement learning and evolution strategies, which enables the search process to efficiently explore a large space of possible architectures. Additionally, we introduce a new regularization term that encourages the discovered architectures to have desirable properties such as spatial hierarchy and parallelism, leading to improved performance and computational efficiency.

Our experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of Auto-DeepLab, with the discovered architectures achieving significant improvements over baseline models and other state-of-the-art segmentation methods. Furthermore, we perform ablation studies to analyze the contributions of different components of our method, providing insights into the importance of various design choices. Finally, we showcase the versatility of Auto-DeepLab by applying it to a variety of tasks beyond semantic segmentation, including instance segmentation and object detection.

In summary, this paper presents Auto-DeepLab, a novel approach to semantic image segmentation that leverages HNAS to discover hierarchical neural network architectures. The proposed method significantly improves upon previous state-of-the-art segmentation models and demonstrates its versatility by being applied to a range of computer vision tasks.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to semantic segmentation called attention-guided supervised contrastive learning (AGSCL). Semantic segmentation is the task of assigning a class label to each pixel in an image, and it is a fundamental problem in computer vision. Contrastive learning has emerged as a powerful tool for learning representations without annotated data, but it has limitations when applied to semantic segmentation tasks. Our approach combines the strengths of contrastive learning with the guidance of supervised attention to improve the accuracy and efficiency of semantic segmentation.

We introduce a novel architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms to focus on the most relevant regions of the image, while simultaneously learning a representation that captures the semantic relationships between pixels. Our approach is trained using a combination of labeled and unlabeled data, and does not require annotated data for the segmentation task. We evaluate our method on several benchmark datasets and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both accuracy and efficiency.

Our key contributions include:

* A novel approach to semantic segmentation that combines contrastive learning with supervised attention
* A new architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms to focus on relevant regions of the image
* A method that learns a representation that captures semantic relationships between pixels without requiring annotated data for the segmentation task
* State-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, outperforming existing methods in both accuracy and efficiency.

Our work has important implications for a wide range of applications, including autonomous driving, medical imaging, and robotics. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach and its potential to improve the efficiency and accuracy of semantic segmentation tasks.

Trace refinement is a technique used to improve the accuracy of numerical solutions to Labelled Markov Decision Processes (LMDPs) by iteratively updating the current estimate of the optimal value function based on the observed traces of the system. However, existing methods for trace refinement are often limited by their reliance on simplistic heuristics or their inability to handle complex structures in the state space.

This paper introduces a new method for trace refinement in LMDPs that addresses these limitations by using a more sophisticated classification of states and a more efficient algorithm for computing the updated value function. Our approach is based on the concept of "nice" partitions, which are used to group states into smaller subsets that can be solved independently. We show that this approach can significantly improve the accuracy and efficiency of trace refinement, allowing for the solution of larger and more complex problems than previously possible.

We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method through experiments on a variety of benchmark problems and compare its performance to existing methods. Our results show that our method is able to obtain higher accuracy and faster convergence than existing methods, while also being easier to implement and interpret.

Overall, this paper presents a significant advancement in the field of trace refinement for LMDPs, providing a new and more effective method for solving these problems that can be applied to a wide range of applications, including robotics, finance, and operations research.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to semantic segmentation called attention-guided supervised contrastive learning (AGSCL). Semantic segmentation is the task of assigning a semantic label to each pixel in an image, and it is a fundamental problem in computer vision. Contrastive learning has emerged as a powerful tool for learning representations without explicit labels, but it has limitations when applied to semantic segmentation tasks. Our approach combines the strengths of contrastive learning with the guidance of supervised learning to improve the accuracy and efficiency of semantic segmentation.

We introduce an attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of different pixels in the image, allowing the model to focus on the most relevant regions when learning the representations. This attention mechanism is combined with a contrastive loss function to encourage the model to learn a robust and discriminative representation that captures the underlying structure of the data. We also propose a novel optimization algorithm that efficiently optimizes the attention weights and the representation learning process.

We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets, including Cityscapes, PASCAL VOC, and COCO. Our experiments show that AGSCL outperforms state-of-the-art semantic segmentation methods, including those that use fully supervised learning. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of our attention mechanism and show that it can be used to identify the most important regions in the image for semantic segmentation.

Our contributions can be summarized as follows:

* We propose a novel approach to semantic segmentation called attention-guided supervised contrastive learning (AGSCL).
* We introduce an attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of different pixels in the image, allowing the model to focus on the most relevant regions when learning the representations.
* We propose a novel optimization algorithm that efficiently optimizes the attention weights and the representation learning process.
* We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark datasets, outperforming state-of-the-art semantic segmentation methods.

Overall, our work presents a significant advancement in the field of semantic segmentation, and it has important implications for a wide range of applications, including autonomous driving, robotics, and medical imaging.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to semi-supervised medical image segmentation and domain adaptation, which is capable of handling uncertainty in both the source and target domains. Our method, called uncertainty-aware multi-view co-training (UAMVCT), combines the strengths of multi-view co-training with the benefits of uncertainty estimation to improve segmentation accuracy in the target domain.

Existing methods for semi-supervised medical image segmentation often rely on simplistic assumptions about the relationship between the source and target domains, such as assuming that the domains share a common feature space or that the target domain can be aligned with the source domain using a simple transformation. However, these assumptions are often violated in real-world scenarios, leading to suboptimal performance.

In contrast, UAMVCT explicitly models the uncertainty in both the source and target domains using probabilistic graphical models. This allows us to capture complex relationships between the domains and to adapt the segmentation model to the target domain in a more principled way. We also introduce an uncertainty-aware loss function that takes into account the uncertainty estimates when training the segmentation model, leading to improved robustness and generalization.

We evaluate our method on several challenging datasets, including brain tumor segmentation from MRI scans and lung nodule detection from CT scans. The results show that UAMVCT outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of segmentation accuracy and robustness across different domains. Additionally, we perform extensive ablation studies to analyze the contributions of different components of our method, providing insights into the effectiveness of uncertainty-aware co-training for medical image segmentation.

Our work has important implications for the development of reliable and robust machine learning models for medical image analysis tasks, where data scarcity and variability are major challenges. By leveraging uncertainty information, UAMVCT offers a promising direction towards improving the performance and reliability of semi-supervised segmentation models in various medical imaging applications.

This paper presents a novel approach for high-resolution segmentation of tooth root fuzzy edges based on polynomial curve fitting with landmark detection. The proposed method utilizes a combination of mathematical morphology and curve fitting techniques to accurately identify and separate the tooth roots from the surrounding dental structures in digital radiographic images.

First, the image is preprocessed using a Gaussian filter to reduce noise and enhance contrast. Then, landmarks are detected on the boundary of the tooth roots using a modified active contours algorithm, which are then used as constraints for the curve fitting process. A polynomial curve is fitted to the landmarks, and the resulting curve is used to segment the tooth roots from the rest of the image.

The proposed method was evaluated on a dataset of 30 digital radiographic images, and the results were compared to those obtained using traditional thresholding and edge detection methods. The results showed that the proposed method produced more accurate and consistent segmentations than the other methods, with an average accuracy rate of 95%. Additionally, the method was found to be robust against variations in image quality and resolution.

The use of polynomial curve fitting with landmark detection offers several advantages over traditional image processing techniques. Firstly, it allows for the preservation of fine details in the image, which is important for accurate segmentation of tooth roots. Secondly, it reduces the risk of under or over-segmentation, which can occur when using thresholding or edge detection methods. Finally, the use of landmarks ensures that the curve fits closely to the true boundary of the tooth roots, resulting in improved accuracy.

Overall, this paper demonstrates a powerful and effective approach for high-resolution segmentation of tooth root fuzzy edges, which has important implications for applications such as orthodontic treatment planning, dental implant design, and oral health diagnosis.

In this paper, we investigate the strong monogamy conjecture in a four-qubit system. The strong monogamy conjecture states that, in any multi-qubit system, the entanglement between two qubits is strongly correlated with the absence of entanglement between the other pairs of qubits. We present experimental and numerical evidence supporting the conjecture in a four-qubit system, where we observe a clear trade-off between the entanglement of different pairs of qubits. Our results provide further insight into the nature of entanglement in multi-qubit systems and have important implications for quantum information processing and communication protocols that rely on entanglement. Specifically, our findings suggest that it may be possible to engineer entangled states with desired properties by carefully designing the interactions between the qubits. These results take us a step closer to harnessing the full potential of multi-qubit systems for quantum computing and related applications.

Image segmentation is a fundamental task in computer vision that involves dividing an image into its constituent parts or objects. It is a challenging problem, especially when dealing with images that have complex structures or unclear boundaries.In this paper,"Image Segmentation by Iterative Inference from Conditional Score Estimation",we propose a novel method for image segmentation using iterative inference and conditional score estimation.
Our approach is based on a probabilistic framework that models the segmentation process as  aMarkov random field(MRF),where each pixel's label depends on the labels of its neighboring pixels.The key insight behind our method is to use conditional scored estimation to efficiently compute the posterior distribution over the image's label field.We devise an algorithm that iteratively updates the estimate of the label fields by maximizing the conditional score function,which leads to accurate segmentation results.
Extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our approach achieves better performance in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency. Moreover, we provide theoretical analysis of the proposed method , ensuring its convergence property and robustness . This work has significant implications  and can be applied in various areas such as object recognition, tracking, and medical imaging.

In this paper, we present SwipeCut, an interactive segmentation method that leverages diversified seed proposals to improve the accuracy and efficiency of image segmentation. Existing interactive segmentation methods rely on a single initial guess or user input, which can be time-consuming and may not capture the desired details. SwipeCut addresses these limitations by generating multiple diverse seed proposals that cover various regions of interest in an image.

We propose a novel algorithm that combines region proposal networks (RPNs) and density-based clustering to generate high-quality seed proposals. The RPN generates a set of regions of interest, which are then used as seeds for density-based clustering. By iteratively adding clusters and refining their boundaries, our method produces a diverse set of seed proposals that cover different parts of the image. We evaluate our method on several benchmark datasets and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art interactive segmentation techniques in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

Furthermore, we introduce a new post-processing technique called boundary smoothness optimization, which enhances the quality of the final segmentation masks produced by SwipeCut. This technique enables us to further improve the segmentation results while maintaining the same level of interactivity. Our experiments demonstrate that SwipeCut achieves state-of-the-art performance on multiple benchmarks while providing a more intuitive and efficient interaction experience for users.

In recent years, human-machine networks have become increasingly complex and ubiquitous, with technology playing a critical role in various aspects of modern life. This has led to a growing interest in understanding the dynamics and implications of these networks, which are shaped by interactions between humans and machines. To address this need, Understanding Human-Machine Networks presents a cross-disciplinary survey that draws on insights from numerous fields including computer science, sociology, psychology, philosophy, and engineering.
The study investigates the different types of human-machine networks and their applications across several domains such as healthcare, transportation, education, and social media. The authors examine how humans interact with machines, focusing both on positive outcomes like improved efficiency and negative consequences such as increased dependency; they also consider ethical concerns surrounding privacy and data security. By providing an overview of current research trends and future directions, it aims to bridge knowledge gaps between disciplines so that we can better comprehend and harnessthe full potential of these networks for innovative problem solving and sustainable development."

This paper proposes a novel approach for resolution enhancement in the recovery of underdrawings using style transfer by generative adversarial deep neural networks (GANs). Underdrawings are rough sketches or preliminary drawings that are often created by artists as a starting point for their artwork. Recovering these underdrawings can provide valuable insights into the creative process and art historical research. However, the low resolution and quality of underdrawings often hinders their analysis and interpretation.

To address this challenge, we leverage the power of GANs to perform style transfer and enhance the resolution of underdrawings. Our approach involves training a GAN on a dataset of high-resolution images, and then using the trained model to transfer the style of these images to the low-resolution underdrawings. We evaluate the effectiveness of our approach through a series of experiments, using various evaluation metrics and comparison with state-of-the-art methods.

The results demonstrate that our method significantly improves the resolution and quality of the recovered underdrawings, outperforming traditional image enhancement techniques. Additionally, we show that the generated high-resolution images preserve the artistic style and details of the original underdrawings, while also providing new insights into the creative process.

Our approach has important implications for art historical research, conservation, and preservation. By enhancing the resolution and quality of underdrawings, art historians and conservators can gain a deeper understanding of the artist's intent and creative process, while also ensuring the long-term preservation of these valuable cultural artifacts.

In conclusion, this paper presents a novel and effective approach for resolution enhancement in the recovery of underdrawings using style transfer by GANs. Our method has the potential to revolutionize the field of art historical research and conservation, enabling the analysis and interpretation of underdrawings in a way that was previously not possible.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to 3D medical image segmentation called Prior-Guided Local Self-supervised Learning (PGL). This method leverages both prior knowledge and local self-supervision to improve the accuracy and efficiency of 3D medical image segmentation.

Existing methods for 3D medical image segmentation often rely on fully supervised learning, which requires a large amount of annotated data. However, obtaining high-quality annotations for 3D medical images is time-consuming and expensive. To address this challenge, we propose PGL, which incorporates prior knowledge into the training process to guide the learning of the segmentation model.

The proposed PGL method consists of two main components: (1) a prior module that encodes prior knowledge from a pre-trained teacher model, and (2) a local self-supervised learning module that uses the encoded prior knowledge to guide the training of the student model. The prior module is trained on a small set of annotated data, while the local self-supervised learning module is trained on a larger set of unannotated data.

We evaluate the performance of PGL using several experiments on publicly available datasets. Our results show that PGL outperforms state-of-the-art self-supervised learning methods in terms of segmentation accuracy and efficiency.
