Joss Whedon, the creator of the hit TV show Buffy the Vampire Slayer, has joined the team behind the upcoming Wonder Woman film, it was announced today.

Whedon, who is known for his work on several popular TV shows and movies, including Angel, Firefly, and The Avengers, will serve as a co-writer and executive producer on the project. He will work alongside director Patty Jenkins and fellow writer Geoff Johns to develop the story and characters for the highly anticipated superhero film.

The move marks a significant coup for Warner Bros., which has been eager to expand its DC Comics universe following the success of last year's Man of Steel. The studio has already announced plans to release a number of DC-related films in the coming years, including Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice and Suicide Squad.

Wonder Woman, which is set to be released in 2017, follows the origin story of the iconic Amazonian warrior princess, played by Gal Gadot. The film promises to explore her early beginnings and rise to becoming one of the world's most powerful heroes.

Joss Whedon expressed his excitement about joining the project, saying, "I'm thrilled to join the talented team behind Wonder Woman and help bring this incredible character to life. I have long admired the strength and courage that Wonder Woman embodies, and I can't wait to see how she will inspire audiences around the world."

Director Patty Jenkins also welcomed Whedon aboard, stating, "We are honored to have Joss on board as we continue to develop this exciting project. His passion and insight will undoubtedly help us create an unforgettable movie experience for fans everywhere."

With Whedon's involvement, fans can expect even more action, suspense, and witty dialogue in what promises to be one of the biggest blockbusters of 2017. With such a powerhouse team at the helm, Wonder Woman is shaping up to be a must-see event for moviegoers of all ages.

Arjen Robben's agent has dismissed rumors that the Dutch winger is set to make a sensational return to Barcelona, insisting that his client remains committed to boyhood club PSV Eindhoven.

Speculation had been mounting that Robben was poised for a dramatic switch to the Nou Camp, six years after leaving the Catalan giants for Bayern Munich. However, Kenyon, who represents the 35-year-old, has moved quickly to quash such talk.

"Arjen is very happy at PSV and has no intention of leaving," Kenyon told BBC Sport. "He's made it clear he wants to see out his playing days in Eindhoven and we're not even considering any other options."

Robben, who won two La Liga titles and the Champions League during his four seasons with Barca, made an emotional return to PSV last summer following a trophy-laden spell with Bayern. Despite his advancing years, he continues to excel on the pitch, netting 12 goals in 24 appearances this term.

While acknowledging the lure of a possible reunion with Ronald Koeman's side, Kenyon stressed that there have been no approaches from Barca or any other clubs.

"Of course, you can never rule anything out entirely in football, but as things stand, Arjen is going nowhere," he said. "We've had no contact from Barcelona or anyone else for that matter. He's happy where he is and so are we."

The news will come as a blow to Barca fans still reeling from the departure of Neymar to Paris Saint-Germain last year. The Blaugrana hierarchy had been exploring ways to strengthen their attacking options, with Robben seen as a viable option given his experience and success at the highest level.

However, it appears that any hopes of a romantic return to the Nou Camp for the flying Dutchman are unlikely to materialize. For now, at least, Robben's focus remains firmly fixed on helping PSV achieve their domestic and European objectives.

Norway has rejected an appeal by music industry groups to overturn a court ruling that allowed file-sharing service Napster to continue operating in the country, BBC News understands.

The Oslo District Court had previously ruled that Napster, which allows users to share digital files including copyrighted music without permission, was not liable for copyright infringement. The court found that the service did not host or distribute any copyrighted content itself and therefore could not be held responsible for its users' actions.

Music industry organizations such as IFPI and GramArt had argued that Napster should be blocked in Norway because it facilitates widespread piracy of copyrighted material. They claimed that the service was in violation of Norwegian law and urged authorities to take action against it.

However, on Tuesday, the appeals court upheld the lower court's decision, finding that Napster was not liable for copyright infringements committed by its users.

"We are pleased with this judgment from the appeals court," said Thomas Rnning, lawyer for Napster. "It is important to protect the rights of consumers and ensure they have access to innovative services like Napster."

Industry watchers say this case highlights the challenges facing entertainment companies attempting to stem the tide of online piracy. Pirated copies of songs and albums are widely available on file-sharing networks, making it difficult for artists and labels to recoup their investments in creating new music. At the same time, many fans feel that they should have the freedom to share music with each other online, just as they would lend CDs to friends in person.

Opponents claim, however, that permitting unregulated file sharing will lead to irreparable damage to the creative industries. Without legal protections, musicians may stop producing altogether if they cannot make money off their work. A report by the Commons Public Accounts Committee has criticized former Prime Ministers Tony Blair and Gordon Brown for their handling of the UK's involvement in the Iraq War and its aftermath.

The report, which was released on Wednesday, accuses both leaders of misleading Parliament and the public about the reasons for going to war and the level of planning that had gone into post-conflict reconstruction.

MPs on the committee heard evidence from a range of witnesses, including senior civil servants, military officers, and diplomats, before compiling their report. They found that the decision to go to war was based on flawed intelligence and that there was a lack of coherent planning for the aftermath.

"The UK's involvement in the Iraq War was founded on a series of flawed assumptions and half-truths," said Meg Hillier, chair of the Public Accounts Committee. "We were told that Saddam Hussein posed an imminent threat to the UK and its allies, but this was not supported by the available intelligence."

The report also criticizes the way in which the government handled the procurement of equipment and supplies for troops during the conflict. It highlights instances where contracts were awarded without proper competition or transparency, leading to significant cost overruns and delays.

In addition, the report raises concerns about the treatment of civilians and prisoners of war, saying that the Ministry of Defence failed to properly investigate allegations of abuse and mistreatment.

Responding to the report, Mr. Blair defended his decision to take the country to war, saying that he acted in good faith based on the information available at the time. He acknowledged that mistakes were made, but argued that they were not intentional.

Mr. Brown, who served as Chancellor under Mr. Blair before becoming Prime Minister himself, declined to comment directly on the report, citing the ongoing Chilcot Inquiry into the Iraq War. However, a spokesperson for the former Prime Minister said that he would be happy to cooperate with any future investigations.

Tom Hanks braved the cold on Tuesday evening as he arrived at the world premiere of his latest film, "A Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood." The movie, which tells the story of a journalist's unlikely friendship with beloved television personality Mr. Rogers, was screened at the Regency Village Theatre in Los Angeles amidst a winter wonderland setting.

Despite the chilly temperatures and snow-covered red carpet, Hanks was all smiles as he greeted fans and posed for photos. The actor, who plays Fred Rogers in the film, looked dapper in a navy blue suit and black tie, accessorizing with a warm beanie and scarf to combat the cold.

Joining Hanks at the premiere were his co-stars Matthew Rhys, Susan Kelechi Watson, and Chris Cooper, as well as director Marielle Heller and producer Youree Henley. Other celebrities in attendance included Hollywood heavyweights like Steven Spielberg, Julia Roberts, and Seth Rogen.

In an interview with Variety, Hanks discussed the challenges of portraying such an iconic figure, saying, "I had to get out of my own way and let Fred Rogers take over." He added, "It was a great lesson in letting go of ego and just allowing yourself to be a vessel for someone else's spirit."

"A Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood" hits theaters nationwide on November 27th.

The UK is set to become a world leader in digital film technology, with the launch of a groundbreaking new network that will revolutionize the way movies are produced, distributed, and consumed.

The Digital Film Network (DFN) is a collaborative project between industry leaders, government agencies, and academic institutions that aims to create a secure and efficient platform for the distribution of films digitally. This cutting-edge technology has the potential to transform the entertainment industry, making it faster, more cost-effective, and more accessible to audiences around the globe.

At the heart of the DFN is a state-of-the-art digital cinema package (DCP) that can transmit high-quality video and audio content to cinemas via satellite or fiber optic connections. This means that movies can be released simultaneously across multiple platforms, including cinemas, streaming services, and home video, without the need for expensive and time-consuming physical print distribution.

"This is a game-changing moment for the film industry," said Arts Minister, Rebecca Mosedale. "The Digital Film Network will help to level the playing field for independent filmmakers and give audiences access to a wider range of diverse and exciting content."

One of the key benefits of the DFN is its ability to support innovative and experimental storytelling. Filmmakers will have greater creative freedom to produce bold and ambitious works, knowing that they can reach a global audience without the financial burden of traditional distribution methods.

Additionally, the DFN will provide real-time analytics and data tracking, allowing distributors and exhibitors to better understand their audiences' preferences and tailor their marketing strategies accordingly. This will enable them to promote films more effectively, improving box office returns and increase revenue opportunities.

The rollout of the DFN is being supported by a major investment from the UK government, as well as partnerships with leading tech companies such as Google and Cisco. The infrastructure is already in place, with over 300 cinemas connected to the network so far, and plans to expand into other countries in the near future.

I'm here today to answer any questions you might have about living with dyscalculia. I was diagnosed with this learning disorder when I was in elementary school, and it's been a wild ride ever since.

For those who don't know, dyscalculia is a neurological disorder that affects the way my brain processes math. It's not that I'm just bad at math - my brain actually has trouble understanding the basic concepts. It's like trying to read a book in a language you don't speak. No matter how hard you try, it just doesn't make sense.

Growing up, I struggled a lot in school. Math was always my worst subject, and I would get anxious and frustrated when it was time to do my homework or take a test. I remember feeling like I was stupid or that there was something wrong with me because I just couldn't seem to get it.

But here's the thing - I'm not stupid. I'm actually pretty smart, and I've learned to adapt and find ways to work around my dyscalculia. I've developed coping strategies and techniques that help me manage my symptoms and do well in school.

One of the biggest challenges I face is remembering numbers and formulas. I have to work extra hard to memorize them, and sometimes they just don't stick. It's like trying to remember a phone number - you know, the one that's always changing? Yeah, that's what it's like.

Another challenge is word problems. I have trouble understanding the context and translating it into math. It's like trying to solve a puzzle blindfolded while eating a bowl of spaghetti. It's messy, and it takes me a lot longer than it would take someone without dyscalculia.

Despite all of this, I've learned to embrace my dyscalculia. It's a part of who I am, and it's not going anywhere. So, I might as well make the best of it, right? I've found

I've been meaning to get back into Attack on Titan for a while now, and I finally did it. And let me tell you, it was totally worth it. The animation is still top-notch, the action scenes are still intense, and the story is still engaging. But you know what the real draw for me was? Eren's character development.

I mean, this guy has been through so much. He's lost his family, his friends, and his sense of self. He's been forced to confront some of the darkest parts of human nature, and he's come out the other side a different person. It's amazing to see how far he's come from the hot-headed, impulsive kid he used to be.

One of the things I love about Eren's character is how complex he is. He's not just a one-dimensional "hero" or "villain." He's got layers, man. He's got fears, doubts, and insecurities. He's got a deep sense of responsibility and a strong sense of justice. And he's not afraid to show his emotions, even when it's hard.

And can we talk about his relationships? His bond with Mikasa is one of the most beautiful things in the show. It's not just a sibling bond, it's a deep emotional connection that goes beyond words. And his dynamic with Levi is fascinating. They're like two sides of the same coin, constantly pushing each other's boundaries and challenging each other to be better.

But what really gets me is how Eren's character has evolved over the course of the show. He's grown from a scared, angry kid into a confident, compassionate leader. He's learned to balance his emotions with his rationality, and he's learned to trust himself and his instincts. It's been a joy to watch him grow and develop, and I can't wait to see what the future holds for him.

Hey fellow riders!

I'm sure some of you may have noticed that I'm in a wheelchair, and I wanted to share my experience of being disabled and riding with all of you.

First of all, let me say that it's not easy. There are days when I feel like giving up, when the pain and fatigue get the better of me and I wonder why I even bother trying. But then there are days like today, when I'm out on my bike, feeling the wind in my hair (okay, so maybe not literally, but you know what I mean) and the sun on my face, and I remember why.

Riding gives me a sense of freedom that I don't often get in other areas of my life. As someone who is unable to walk, many everyday activities can be a challenge, from grocery shopping to simply getting around my own home. But on my bike, none of that matters. I'm not limited by my disability, I'm free to go wherever the road takes me.

Of course, there are challenges that come with riding as a disabled person. Finding accessible routes can be tough, and sometimes I have to get creative with my route-planning. And yes, there are definitely days when the pain and fatigue make it harder to ride than others. But the benefits far outweigh the difficulties.

Not only does riding give me a sense of freedom, but it also helps me mentally. It's a way for me to clear my head and relieve stress, which is especially important when dealing with the daily struggles of living with a disability. Plus, it's a great workout - something that's important for everyone, but especially for those of us who may have limitations on our physical activity.

So, to any other disabled riders out there, I want to say keep at it! Don't let your disability hold you back from experiencing the joy of riding. And to able-bodied riders, please be mindful of accessibility when planning routes and events - a little bit of consideration can go a long way in making the cycling community more inclusive for

As a long-time fan of both GameStop (GME) and AMC Entertainment (AMC), I've been following their stock performance with great interest. Recently, I've noticed a trend that I think could be a game-changer for both companies: the rise of bistocksuality.

For those who may not be familiar, bistocksuality refers to the practice of holding two stocks at once, typically in a 50/50 split. This strategy allows investors to combine the benefits of both stocks, potentially creating a more stable and diversified portfolio.

So, how could this apply to GME and AMC? Well, both companies have faced significant challenges in recent years, with the COVID-19 pandemic having a particularly harsh impact on their businesses. However, they've both shown remarkable resilience and adaptability, and I believe they're poised for a strong comeback.

By investing in both GME and AMC, bistocksual investors can take advantage of their unique strengths and growth opportunities. GameStop has been expanding its offerings to include more digital products and services, while AMC has been investing heavily in new technologies and amenities to enhance the movie-going experience.

Moreover, bistocksuality can provide a hedge against potential volatility in either stock. If one company experiences a setback, the other can help offset the losses. And if both companies continue to perform well, investors can enjoy the benefits of diversification and potentially increased returns.

Of course, there are no guarantees in the stock market, and bistocksuality is not without its risks. However, I believe that a judicious approach to investing in both GME and AMC could be a winning strategy for those willing to take a long-term view.

Hey fellow writers! I'm here to talk about two of my favorite things: spectacular writing and character development!

We all know that great characters are at the heart of any good story, and as writers, it's our job to bring them to life on the page. But what does it mean to have well-developed characters? For me, it means creating characters that feel like real people - flaws, quirks, and all.

One way to do this is by giving your characters unique personalities, backstories, and motivations. Think about what drives them, what scares them, and what makes them tick. This will help you create authentic dialogue and actions that ring true for your readers.

Another important aspect of character development is showing how your characters grow and change over time. No one stays the same forever, and your characters shouldn't either. Maybe they learn something new about themselves or the world around them, or maybe they go through a traumatic experience that shapes who they become. Whatever it is, make sure it feels organic and natural for the character.

Now, let's talk about spectacular writing. We've all read books where the writing is so beautiful, it takes our breath away. It's like the words on the page come alive and transport us to another world. That's what we should strive for in our own writing.

To achieve this, focus on using descriptive language that paints vivid pictures in the reader's mind. Don't just tell your readers what's happening, show them. Use sensory details to create an immersive experience - what sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and textures would your character be experiencing in a given scene? Make your readers feel like they're right there with your characters.

Another important aspect of spectacular writing is paying attention to sentence structure and pacing. Vary your sentence length and structure to keep your readers engaged. Short sentences can create a sense of urgency, while longer ones can build suspense. And don't forget about symbolism and metaphors - these can add depth and meaning to your writing that will leave your readers thinking long

I can't believe how different my life is now compared to five years ago. It feels like just yesterday I was struggling to make ends meet, working multiple part-time jobs and living in a tiny studio apartment with my partner.

Now, we're both successful professionals, living in a beautiful home with our two adorable kids. We have a nice car, take annual vacations, and even have a decent amount saved up for retirement. It's amazing how much things can change in such a short period of time.

One of the biggest differences is the way we spend our free time. Back then, we used to have to be so careful about every little expense, cutting coupons and scouring thrift stores for deals. Now, while we still enjoy being frugal, we don't have to worry as much about money. We love hosting dinner parties and game nights with friends, trying out new restaurants, and exploring local attractions.

Our social circle has also evolved. We've made some great new friends through work and our kid's activities, but we've also had to say goodbye to some old friends who didn't quite fit into our new lifestyle. It's funny how priorities shift when you start a family  suddenly, having a strong support system and people who share your values become way more important than having a big group of party pals.

Another major difference is the tech advancements that have been made over the past five years. Remember when virtual reality was still a novelty? Now it's becoming increasingly commonplace! My partner works in IT and he's always bringing home cool gadgets and software to try out. And let's not forget about smart homes  our house is full of voice assistants, automated lights, and security cameras. It's like we're living in the future!

Lastly, I think our views on politics and society have matured. There are so many issues that we never really paid attention to before (or maybe ignored because they seemed too daunting), like climate change or economic inequality. Becoming parents has given us a new perspective

I've always wondered why getting sucker punched hurts so much more than a punch of the same power in an actual fight. It's like, you're just walking along, minding your own business, and then BAM! Someone comes out of nowhere and hits you with a punch that wouldn't even be that hard if you were expecting it. But because you didn't see it coming, it feels like a freight train hit you.

I mean, I've been in a few fights before, and when you're prepared for a punch, you can brace yourself for impact. You tense up your muscles, grit your teeth, and take the hit. Sure, it still hurts, but it's nothing compared to the shock and pain of a sucker punch.

But when you're blindsided, your body doesn't have time to react. Your muscles are relaxed, your guard is down, and suddenly you're trying to process what just happened while your brain is still trying to figure out what's going on. It's like your body is playing catch-up, trying to make sense of the sudden trauma.

And let's not forget about the element of surprise. When someone sneaks up on you and hits you without warning, your brain goes into overdrive. You're thinking, "Wait, what just happened? Did I really just get hit?" Meanwhile, your body is trying to deal with the physical effects of the punch, which only adds to the confusion and disorientation.

So yeah, getting sucker punched hurts way more than a punch in an actual fight because it's not just about the physical force of the blow  it's also about the mental and emotional shock of being caught off guard. It's like your whole system is thrown off balance, and it takes a minute to regain your footing (literally and figuratively).

Anyway, that's my theory. Has anyone else ever thought about this or am I just weird for dwelling on stuff like this?

Hmm, where do I start with this one? It's like, I get that people want to have fun and all, but why do they need drugs to do it? Can't they just, like, enjoy themselves without having to resort to substances?

I mean, I see it everywhere - at parties, clubs, even in the streets. People smoking weed, snorting coke, popping pills. It's like, what happened to good old-fashioned socializing? Why can't we just hang out and have a good time without the need for drugs?

And don't even get me started on the dangers of drug use. We all know the risks - addiction, health problems, impaired judgment. It's scary stuff. But still, people keep using them. Like, what's the appeal? Is getting high really worth risking your health and well-being?

I guess what bothers me most is how casual everyone seems to be about it. Drugs are just normalized nowadays. Everyone's doing them, so it's seen as no big deal. But it should be a big deal! We need to stop trivializing drug use and realize the harm it can cause.

It's like, I get that life can be stressful and overwhelming sometimes, but turning to drugs isn't the answer. There are other ways to cope - exercise, meditation, spending time with loved ones. Healthy habits that won't damage our bodies or minds.

So, yeah, I guess that's my two cents. Doing drugs shouldn't be the norm. Let's strive for a society where we can have fun and relax without relying on harmful substances. Who's with me?

The worst part is the social distancing measures. We're not allowed to sit near each other, let alone hang out or have any kind of social interaction. It's like they're trying to turn us into robots who only care about following rules instead of human beings who need connection and community.

I miss the days when we could chat with friends between classes, share snacks, or just relax together during lunch. Now, everything feels so sterile and isolated. Even our extracurricular activities are cancelled or heavily restricted. Sports teams are limited to individual drills, band practice is done online, and club meetings are rare and often virtual.

It's not just the students who are suffering either. Teachers seem stressed and overworked, constantly having to enforce these ridiculous rules while trying to still teach us something. They deserve better too.

I know safety is important, but this isn't the way to do it. We're being treated like prisoners in our own school. When will it end? How much longer until we can go back to being normal teenagers again?

Hey fellow Redditors,

I'm reaching out because I think I might have thanatophobia, also known as death anxiety. It's been affecting my life for a while now and I really need some help.

For those who don't know, thanatophobia is an excessive fear of death or dying. It's not just a normal fear of death, but an irrational and persistent one that interferes with daily life. And that's exactly what it's doing to me.

I can't stop thinking about death. Every day, every night, it's all I can think about. I lay in bed at night, unable to sleep, my mind racing with thoughts of mortality. I worry about myself, my loved ones, random accidents, illnesses - you name it. I feel like I'm constantly on edge, waiting for something bad to happen.

It's affecting my relationships too. My friends and family are starting to notice how much I've changed. I avoid social events, I don't want to go out and do things anymore. I used to love hiking and camping, but now the thought of being in the wilderness, away from medical help, terrifies me.

Work is suffering too. I can't concentrate, I make mistakes, I'm always distracted. My boss has noticed and I'm worried I might lose my job.

I've tried therapy, but it doesn't seem to be working. Maybe I'm not doing it right? Maybe I need a different therapist? I don't know.

That's why I'm turning to you guys. Have any of you experienced this? What did you do to cope? Any advice would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks for reading and sorry if this was long-winded.

I'm sick and tired of playing survival mods with clunky, unintuitive, and downright frustrating mechanics. It's time for developers to step up their game and make survival mode support a top priority.

I understand that adding new features and content is important, but what good are all those shiny new guns and skins when the core gameplay experience is broken? I've lost count of how many times I've died because my character decided to climb a ladder instead of taking cover behind a nearby wall. Or how often I've had to tediously scavenge for resources because the game won't let me pick up items from more than five feet away.

It's not just about convenience either. Survival mode is supposed to be challenging, but it shouldn't feel like the game is actively working against you. When I'm stuck fighting the controls instead of the zombies, it takes away from the immersion and enjoyment of the game. And don't even get me started on the save system  there's nothing more infuriating than losing an hour of progress because the game decides to crash or your character dies in a cheap way.

I know some devs are doing it right  look at games like DayZ and Rust, where survival is at the forefront of the design. They may not have the flashiest graphics or the most elaborate storylines, but they nail the survival experience. Their success shows that players are hungry for this type of gameplay, so why aren't more developers paying attention?

I'm calling out to all the developers out there  please, take a closer look at your survival mode support. Make it a priority, put some real thought into it, and test it thoroughly. Your players will thank you, and your game will be better off for it. Let's make survival gaming great again!

Sure! Here's a possible Reddit post:

Hey fellow Redditors,

I just wanted to remind everyone that Exodus is a wallet, not an exchange. I've seen a lot of people confusion about this lately, so I thought it was important to clarify.

Exodus is a software wallet that allows you to store, send, and receive cryptocurrencies. It's a great option for those who want to have full control over their coins and don't want to rely on a centralized exchange.

However, Exodus is not an exchange. This means that you cannot buy or sell cryptocurrencies directly within the wallet. If you want to acquire new coins or exchange one cryptocurrency for another, you'll need to use a separate exchange service.

I know this can be a bit inconvenient, but it's important to understand the difference between a wallet and an exchange. Exodus is designed to provide a secure and private way to store and manage your cryptocurrencies, while exchanges are designed to facilitate the buying and selling of those currencies.

So, if you're looking for a wallet that gives you full control over your coins, Exodus is a great option. But if you're looking to buy or sell cryptocurrencies, you'll need to look elsewhere.

I hope this helps clarify things! Let me know if you have any other questions.

I'm writing this post as a warning to others who may be considering a career in the tech industry, particularly in startups. I'm sure my story isn't unique, but I want to share my experience in the hopes that it might help others avoid the same pitfalls.

I've been in the tech industry for over a decade, and I've seen my fair share of ups and downs. But nothing could have prepared me for the nightmare that I'm currently living.

I joined a startup a few years ago, excited by the prospect of working on cutting-edge technology and being part of a small, agile team. Things started off well enough, but over time, I began to notice some red flags. The CEO was a bit too obsessed with growth, and seemed to prioritize expansion over everything else. The company was constantly hiring, but there was no clear strategy in place for how to integrate new employees into the team.

Despite these concerns, I tried to stay positive and focus on my work. But things only got worse. The CEO's obsession with growth led to a culture of burnout, where employees were expected to work long hours, 7 days a week. The lack of clear communication and strategy led to confusion and chaos, with different teams working on the same projects without knowing it.

And then, the final straw. The company decided to implement a "permanent MET" policy, where employees were expected to be available 24/7, 365 days a year. No vacation time, no sick leave, no mental health days. If you needed time off for any reason, you had to get permission from the CEO himself.

I knew I had to get out of there, but it wasn't easy. The company had a strict non-compete clause, and I knew that if I left, I wouldn't be able to work in the tech industry for a year. But I couldn't stay in a job that was destroying my mental and physical health.

I finally managed to escape, but the damage had already been done. I'm still struggling to recover from the experience

...you lose track of time. Minutes feel like hours, hours feel like days, and days feel like a lifetime. Every moment spent away from your loved one feels like an eternity.

You start to forget who you are without them. Your interests, your hobbies, your passions - they all take a backseat to the all-consuming love you have for this person. You find yourself doing things you never thought you'd do, saying things you never thought you'd say, all in the name of love.

You begin to lose your sense of self, your identity. You start to see yourself through their eyes, and not necessarily in a positive way. You feel like you're not good enough, that you'll never measure up to their standards. You start to doubt your own worth, your own value.

But despite all of this, you can't help but be drawn back to them. Like a moth to a flame, you're helplessly drawn to the love they offer, the comfort they provide. You know it may not be healthy, that it may not be sustainable, but you can't help yourself.

Losing yourself in love can be both exhilarating and terrifying. It's a rollercoaster of emotions, a tidal wave of feelings that can leave you breathless and bruised. But it's also a reminder that we're human, that we're capable of feeling such deep and powerful emotions.

So even though it's scary, even though it's difficult, I wouldn't trade the experience of losing myself in love for anything. It's a reminder that we're alive, that we're capable of love and being loved in return. And that, to me, is the greatest gift of all.

I've noticed a trend lately where people seem to think that just because they have an opinion, it automatically deserves to be heard, considered, and validated by everyone. Newsflash: it doesn't work that way.

Having an opinion is a fundamental right, but it doesn't mean that opinion is automatically worthy of attention or validation. In fact, some opinions are downright harmful, misinformed, or just plain stupid. And you know what? People have the right to ignore them, dismiss them, or even call them out for what they are.

It's like this: just because you have the right to free speech, it doesn't mean you have the right to force others to listen to you or take your opinions seriously. If you want people to listen to your opinions, you need to earn their respect and attention through thoughtful, well-reasoned arguments and a willingness to listen to others in return.

But here's the thing: too many people these days seem to think that their opinions are somehow sacred, and that everyone should be forced to listen to them and validate their feelings. Sorry, but that's not how it works. If you want to be heard, you need to put in the effort to make your voice worth hearing.

And don't get me started on social media. It's like people think that just because they have a platform, they can spout off any nonsense they want and everyone should just nod along in agreement. Newsflash: that's not how it works. If you want to be taken seriously, you need to put in the effort to educate yourself, think critically, and engage in respectful dialogue.

So, to all the people out there who think their opinions are the center of the universe: get over yourselves. Your opinions are not automatically worthy of attention or validation just because you have them. If you want to be heard, you need to earn it. And if you can't handle that, then maybe it's time to take a step back and reevaluate why you think your opinions are so damn important in the first place.

Firstly, let me tell you that UAD (Universal Audio) plugins are amazing, but they can be pretty demanding on your computer's hardware. So, you'll need a system or laptop that meets their minimum requirements, which are:

* Operating System: Windows 10 (64-bit)
* Processor: Intel Core i5 or AMD equivalent
* RAM: 8 GB or more
* GPU: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 or Radeon Pro WX 3270 (or better)
* Storage: 256 GB SSD or larger solid-state drive
* USB Ports: Available for peripherals and dongles

Now, here are some systems and laptops that I've found to work well with UAD products:

1. Dell XPS Tower Special Edition - This desktop machine is a powerhouse and can handle everything I throw at it. It has plenty of ports for my Apollo interface, satellite speakers, and other gear. The only downside is that it's a bit pricey, but worth every penny if you want top-notch performance.
2. HP Envy x360 - If you prefer a laptop, this one is an excellent choice. It's got a great keyboard, a responsive touchscreen, and enough power to run all my UAD plugins without any glitches. Plus, it looks sleek and feels sturdy as hell.

I'm still surprised that Firefox still can't save web pages as PDFs while preserving hyperlinks. It's been years since this feature was requested, and yet, every time I try to save a webpage as a PDF, the links are lost.

I've tried all the workarounds:

* Printing to PDF using the built-in print function
* Using the "Save as PDF" extension
* Using the "Print Friendly & PDF" extension

But none of them work reliably. Sometimes the links are preserved, sometimes they're not. It's like playing a game of roulette every time I want to save a webpage as a PDF.

I've also tried using other browsers, but they all have the same issue. It's like the browser developers have decided that preserving hyperlinks in PDFs is a feature that nobody needs.

I find it especially frustrating because I often need to save web pages as PDFs for work. I have to manually recreate the links or use a different browser, which is a huge hassle.

I've been going to therapy for a few months now, and I've been asked by a few friends what it's like. I thought I'd share my experience here in case anyone is curious.

My therapist is a kind, compassionate person who creates a safe and non-judgmental space for me to talk about my feelings and experiences. She listens actively, asking thoughtful questions and providing insightful feedback. She also gives me practical tools and strategies to help me manage my emotions and behaviors.

One of the things I appreciate most about therapy is that it's a space where I can be completely honest without fear of being criticized or judged. It's a place where I can explore my thoughts and feelings without worrying about how they might be received. This has been incredibly liberating for me, as I've been able to confront some of the things that have been holding me back and work towards making positive changes in my life.

Another benefit of therapy has been the increased self-awareness it's brought me. Through our sessions, I've come to understand myself better, including my patterns of behavior and the underlying causes of some of my emotions. This has helped me to be more mindful and intentional in my interactions with others, and has also helped me to develop healthier coping mechanisms.

Of course, therapy isn't always easy. It can be challenging to confront difficult emotions and experiences, and there have been times when I've felt uncomfortable or frustrated. It is not appropriate or respectful to suggest removing any body part, including the vagina, as a solution to any medical condition, including bacterial vaginosis (BV). Every body part has its own important functions and removing them can cause serious harm and trauma.

Instead, there are many effective ways to treat and prevent BV that do not involve surgery or removing body parts. These include:

* Maintaining good hygiene and washing the genital area with mild soap and water
* Not douching or using vaginal deodorants
* Avoiding sexual intercourse during an episode of BV
* Taking antibiotics prescribed by a healthcare provider
* Using a vaginal cream or gel that contains ingredients such as clindamycin or metronidazole
* Taking probiotics to promote the growth of good bacteria in the vagina
* Avoiding tight-fitting clothing and wearing breathable cotton underwear
* Avoiding irritants such as scented soaps, bubble baths, and perfumes
* Avoiding smoking and alcohol

It's important to consult a healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and treatment of BV. They can help determine the best treatment option for each individual and provide guidance on how to prevent future episodes.

It's important to remember that the vagina is a self-cleaning organ and maintaining good hygiene and avoiding irritants can help to prevent BV. It's also important to prioritize overall health and well-being by eating a balanced diet, getting enough sleep, and managing stress.

When I was younger, I used to see my parents as superheroes - they were always right, always knew what to do, and could solve any problem that came their way. They were my rock, my safety net, and my guiding light. As I grew older, I began to realize that my parents weren't perfect, that they were human beings with their own flaws and limitations.

At first, it was little things - they would forget something important, or make a mistake when calculating a tip at a restaurant. But over time, it became more apparent that they were capable of making bigger mistakes, ones that affected me directly. They would give me bad advice, or make decisions that ultimately hurt me. It was hard for me to accept, but I had to face the fact that my parents weren't infallible.

As much as I hate to admit it, seeing my parents as capable of error has been a difficult adjustment. I feel like I've lost something precious, something that provided me with a sense of security and comfort. Now, instead of looking up to them as idols, I have to view them as people who are doing the best they can, just like everyone else.

Sometimes, I catch myself wishing I could go back to the days when my parents were invincible in my eyes. Life seemed simpler then; there was less pressure on me to figure everything out on my own. But deep down, I know that's not healthy thinking. My parents aren't perfect, and neither am I. We all make mistakes, we all learn from them (or at least try to), and we all grow because of them.

Even though it's tough to let go of that childhood innocence, I'm grateful for the newfound appreciation and understanding I have for my parents. They may not be perfect, but they love me unconditionally. They may make mistakes, but they mean well. And in the end, they're still my heroes - just not Superman and Wonder Woman, but real-life heroes who show me every day what strength, resilience, and courage look like.

I'm on the hunt for anime that have done their research and then some! You know, shows where it's clear that the creators are passionate about the subject matter and went above and beyond to get everything right. Maybe they consulted with experts in the field or delved deep into historical records - whatever it is, I want to see it!

For example, let me tell you about this one show called "Ghost in the Shell". It's set in a dystopian cyberpunk future and boy does it deliver on the details. The creators must have spent hours upon hours studying up on cybernetic enhancements and artificial intelligence because every aspect of those technologies feels spot-on. They even got the CEO of a major robotics company to advise on the production! Now that's dedication.

But my love for detail-oriented anime doesn't stop at sci-fi. Give me a good old-fashioned historical epic any day! Take "The Tatami Galaxy" for instance. This surrealist masterpiece takes place in modern Japan but draws heavily from traditional Japanese folklore and mythology. And let me tell you, the intricate designs on each character's yukata (traditional robes) are almost as breathtaking as the philosophical themes explored throughout the series. Could they have skimped out on either? Easily! But no, instead, they chose to push boundaries left and right. That's what makes these shows stand out. That's why I'm looking for more recommendations along these lines.

So please share your favorite overly detailed anime gems below! Whether it be historical dramas, hardcore action fests, or slow burn slice-of-life series; if the creators clearly put in the extra effort for accuracy, I need to see them! Let's keep the spirit of meticulousness alive and celebrate anime greatness together!

Hey fellow Redditors! I've been trying to live a more sustainable life for the past year, and I'm curious what changes others have made to reduce their impact on the environment.

Personally, I've made a few changes that have had a significant impact:

* I stopped using plastic bags and straws. Instead, I carry reusable bags and water bottles with me everywhere I go. It's amazing how much waste these simple items can save!
* I started buying produce from local farmers markets instead of grocery stores. Not only is it better quality, but it also reduces transportation emissions.
* I invested in energy-efficient light bulbs and turned off lights/electronics when they're not being used. My electricity bill has gone down noticeably since making this change.
* I sold my car and now bike or use public transit to get around. This has saved money on gas, maintenance, and parking fees while also getting some exercise.
* I try to shop secondhand before buying new clothes or household items. There are so many great thrift shops and online marketplaces where you can find unique (and often higher quality) items at a fraction of the cost. Plus, less stuff going into landfills.
* Speaking of laundry, I switched detergent brands and opted for an eco-friendly option without harsh chemicals. Not sure if it makes a huge difference, but every little bit counts!
* Lastly, I've begun investing in reusable products like cloth diapers, stainless steel water bottles, beeswax wraps (instead of Glad wrap), etc. The initial costs might seem steep for some items, however, knowing that each purchase means fewer trips to the trash dumpster over time feels satisfying. And honestly? Most of them are nicer than their disposable counterparts anyways!

So what about you all? What stepsbig or smallhave you taken toward living a greener lifestyle? Let's swap tips and inspire one another to create some positive environmental change!

I've been unable to shake this feeling of regret for the past few days. It's like a nagging voice in the back of my head, constantly reminding me of what could have been.

I had always dreamed of becoming a professional musician, but I never had the courage to pursue it seriously. I was too afraid of failure, too afraid of not being good enough. So, I settled for a safe and stable job that left me unfulfilled and unhappy.

But then, one day, I stumbled upon an opportunity to open for a well-known band at a local venue. It was a chance to finally showcase my talent and potentially launch my career. I knew it was a long shot, but I couldn't help but feel a spark of hope.

The problem was, I hesitated. I let fear and self-doubt hold me back once again. And now, as I sit here thinking about what could have been, all I can do is wonder what would have happened if I had taken that chance.

Would I have blown them away with my performance? Would I have landed a record deal? Would I be living my dream right now?

These questions haunt me every day. The thought of my lost chance eats away at me, leaving a bitter taste in my mouth.

I know I'll never know the answer to these questions, but that doesn't make it any easier. All I can do is try to learn from my mistake and move forward, hoping that someday I'll get another chance to chase my dreams. But until then, the what-ifs will continue to taunt me, a constant reminder of my missed opportunity.

I recently watched both "Onward" and "Soul" and I have to say, I enjoyed "Onward" way more. Don't get me wrong, "Soul" had its moments, but it didn't capture my imagination quite like "Onward" did.

First off, the world-building in "Onward" is top-notch. The movie takes place in a suburban fantasy world where magic exists but has largely fallen out of use, and the attention to detail in every aspect of the environment is impressive. From the enchanted creatures roaming the streets to the magical architecture, everything feels so lived-in and immersive. In contrast, "Soul" takes place in a pretty standard cityscape with some nice visual touches, but it doesn't come close to the sheer wonder and charm of "Onward"'s setting.

Another thing that sets "Onward" apart is its characters. Ian Lightfoot (Tom Holland) and Barley Lightfood (Chris Pratt) are absolute delights as two brothers on a quest to bring their father back from the dead. Their rapport and banter are hilarious and heartwarming, and their personalities feel so well-developed and relatable. Joe Gardner (Jamie Foxx) in "Soul," on the other hand, took a bit longer to grow on me. He's definitely an interesting character, but there's something about his arc that felt a little predictable and surface-level compared to the depth we see in "Onward."

Lastly, I think the themes explored in "Onward" resonate much stronger than those in "Soul." Both movies deal with big questions about life, death, family, and purpose, but "Onward" tackles these ideas in a more nuanced and mature way. We get to see how each character grapples with their own sense of identity and loss, and how they learn to appreciate what truly matters in life. While "Soul" tries to pack in too many philosophical concepts without fully committing to any one idea.

I am so tired of never being able to have a conversation about women's issues without it turning into a debate about men's issues. Every time we try to talk about something that disproportionately affects women, like reproductive rights or sexual harassment, someone inevitably pipes up with "but what about the men?"

It's like, hello, we're not talking about you right now. We're talking about the systemic problems that women face every day. Can't we have one conversation where we don't have to cater to the male perspective?

And don't even get me started on the constant need to justify why women's issues are important. It's like, do we really have to explain why equal pay for equal work is a basic human right? Or why not being able to control our own bodies is a problem? It's exhausting.

I know that men can also face discrimination and marginalization, and those issues are important too. But let's be real, they're not the same as the ones women face. Women are still paid less than men on average, we're underrepresented in politics and business, and we're more likely to experience violence and harassment. And yet, whenever we try to address these issues, we're met with resistance and defensiveness from some men who feel like their privilege is being threatened.

Can't we just have a conversation about women's issues without having to constantly prove our worthiness of discussion? Can't we just acknowledge that women deserve the same respect and equality as men, and start working towards making that a reality?

And let me tell you, it's not an easy task, especially when you consider the demographics of school bus riders - think about how challenging your average middle-schooler can be.

Bus drivers also play a vital role in ensuring that kids get to school on time, ready to learn. If they weren't doing their jobs effectively, thousands of students across the country would miss out on valuable learning hours as a result of being late or absent due to unreliable (or non-existent!) transportation. That has long term effects on academic achievement and future career success that cannot be overstated. Not only this but many working parents rely heavily upon these services so they themselves may go work knowing their child(ren) will arrive home safe and sound after school lets out.. We simply couldn't function without dedicated professionals like them keeping everything running smoothly behind the scenes!

And yet... what do they get paid? A paltry sum! Many barely crack minimum wage despite dealing daily with responsibilities tantamount to those shouldered by public transit bus drivers, emergency responders, police officers combined into one person - all while keeping up positivity among elementary aged passengers (who often look forward immenselyto riding the big yellow bus). Oh yeah, I forgot another major part of their duties: random drug testing just like commercial truck drivers must endure since technically speaking our precious children's lives rest literally 'in their hands' during each trip; however no such pay increase accompanies this added responsibility nor associated paranoia, stress etcetera either thankless though it may entail. It breaks my heart thinking we place such little value on lives devoted entirely towards helping raise our society's youth especially

Hey fellow Redditors,

I've noticed a lot of questions and confusion lately about the price difference between certain products, specifically in the electronics and tech industry. I work in the industry and wanted to shed some light on the various factors that contribute to the price difference between similar products.

First and foremost, research and development (R&D) plays a huge role in determining the price of a product. Companies invest a significant amount of money into R&D to create new technologies, improve existing ones, and make sure their products are top-notch. This investment is typically reflected in the price of the product.

Another factor is the quality of materials used. Higher-end products often use premium materials that are more expensive to produce and source. For example, a smartphone with a glass back may cost more than one with a plastic back, as glass is a more expensive material.

Manufacturing processes also contribute to the price difference. Some products are made with more advanced manufacturing processes that are more expensive, such as 3D printing or precision machining. These processes can result in higher-quality products, but they also drive up the cost.

Certifications and compliances can also impact the price of a product. Some products, such as those in the medical or aerospace industries, require specific certifications to ensure they meet certain safety and performance standards. Obtaining these certifications can be a costly process, and the cost is often passed on to the consumer.

Lastly, brand reputation and marketing play a significant role in pricing. Companies with a strong brand reputation and extensive marketing efforts often charge more for their products because they can. Consumers are willing to pay a premium for products from well-known and trusted brands.

I hope this helps clarify some of the reasons why similar products can have such vastly different price tags. It's not always just about the cost of materials and production; there are many other factors at play.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you have any other questions about product pricing? Let's discuss in the comments!

Hey fellow Raiders,

I've been thinking about energy recharges and attack sands a lot lately, and I wanted to get some thoughts down on paper (or screen, I guess). It seems like there's always debate about which one is better, so I thought it would be helpful to break down the pros and cons of each.

First off, let's talk about energy recharges. These things are amazing for keeping your weapons and abilities fueled up during long fights or when you're out exploring. They're especially useful if you have a weapon that uses a lot of energy, like a plasma sword or something. The big downside to energy recharges though is that they take up a lot of inventory space, and they can be pretty expensive to buy or craft. Plus, if you're in a tight spot and need health, an energy recharge isn't going to do much for you.

Now, let's look at attack sands. These little guys pack a punch, and they're super cheap to buy or craft. They also don't take up much inventory space, so you can carry a bunch with you without feeling weighed down. The main issue with attack sands is that they don't give you any health back, so you need to make sure you're not taking too much damage while using them. Another thing to consider is that they can only be used once before they break, so you'll need to replace them often.

So, which one should you choose? Honestly, it depends on your playstyle and what you need in a given situation. If you're someone who likes to go in guns blazing and doesn't mind sacrificing a bit of health, then attack sands might be the way to go. On the other hand, if you prefer to take a more strategic approach and want to keep your weapons charged up for longer periods of time, then energy recharges are probably your best bet.

What do you guys think? Have any tips for when to use energy recharges versus attack sands? Let me know in the comments!

I'm writing this post to share my thoughts on serving another year in our community, but not necessarily as a lead. I know some of you might be thinking, "Why would I want to do that? Being a lead is the best way to make a difference!" And while it's true that leads play a crucial role in our community, there are plenty of other ways to make a positive impact without being in a leadership position.

For those who don't know me, I've been involved in various open-source communities for several years now, and I've had the privilege of serving as a lead for one of them. It was an incredible experience, and I learned a lot from it. However, after much reflection, I realized that I want to take a step back and focus on other areas of contribution.

Here are a few reasons why:

1. **Burnout**: Let's face it, being a lead can be exhausting. There are so many responsibilities, from managing people to dealing with conflicts, that it can be hard to keep up. By serving in a different capacity, I can still contribute without shouldering all that stress.
2. **Exploring new interests**: As a lead, it's easy to get stuck in a particular niche or area of expertise. While that's great for depth of knowledge, sometimes it's nice to branch out and try something new. Serving in a supporting role allows me to explore other parts of the project and learn fresh skills.
3. **Empowering others**: One of the most fulfilling aspects of being a lead is seeing someone you mentored or supported grow into a leadership role themselves. By stepping aside and letting someone else take the reins, I can help empower the next generation of contributors.
4. **Perspective**: When you're in a leadership position, it's easy to get caught up in the big picture and lose sight of the little things. By serving in a supporting role, I can focus more on the details and provide feedback from a different perspective.

At first, I thought it was a telemarketer or survey company, so my instinct was to hang up immediately. But something about it didn't feel quite right, so I decided to play along and see where it went.

The woman on the other end introduced herself as a researcher from the University of Toronto, and she sounded legitimate enough. She explained that they were conducting a study on human behavior and decision-making, and that they had chosen me at random to participate. The questions she asked were pretty interesting, actually - things like how I make decisions in various situations, what factors influence my choices, and how I weigh risks and benefits. Cooperative cooperations, where members own and control the means of production, are a fascinating concept that challenges traditional understandings of capitalism and socialism. If such cooperatives were to compete in a free market, it raises the question of whether they would be considered capitalist or socialist.

On one hand, cooperative cooperations are owned and controlled by their members, which aligns with the principles of socialism. In a socialist system, the means of production are collectively owned and controlled by the people, rather than by private individuals or corporations. Additionally, cooperative cooperations often prioritize the needs of their members and the community over profits, which is a key aspect of socialist ideology.

On the other hand, cooperative cooperations operating in a free market are still subject to market forces and must compete with other businesses to succeed. They must innovate, produce goods and services that people want, and operate efficiently to stay afloat. In this sense, they share similarities with capitalist enterprises, which are driven by the pursuit of profit and competition.

So, would cooperative cooperations competing in a free market be considered capitalist or socialist? The answer may depend on how one defines capitalism and socialism.

Some might argue that cooperative cooperations are a form of socialism because they are owned and controlled by their members, prioritize collective needs over profits, and operate in the context of a market that is not fully free (as there are still regulations and government intervention in the economy). In this view, the fact that they compete in a market does not negate their socialist characteristics.

Others might argue that cooperative cooperations are a form of capitalism because they operate in a market, are driven by competition, and seek to innovate and expand their operations to increase their market share. In this view, the fact that they are owned and controlled by their members is a unique feature of this type of capitalism, but it does not change the fundamental nature of the system.

But even though I've come so far, I can't help but wonder when everything will return to normal. When will I be able to go a day without thinking about that connection? When will I be able to scrolling through my feeds without feeling a twinge of guilt or FOMO?

I know it's unrealistic to expect everything to go back to the way it was before. That connection has left a lasting impact on me, and I'll always carry it with me in some way. But I'm hoping that with time, the memories will fade, and I'll be able to move on completely.

So, to all my fellow quitters out there, I ask you: how long did it take for you to feel like yourself again? Did it take a year? Two years? Five? I'm curious to know if I'm on the right track, or if I'm just being too impatient.

Thanks for reading, and I look forward to your responses.

So, did any of you guys go through something similar? Did it take some getting used to, or was it pretty much instantly comfortable for you? How do you deal with awkward situations where people use your old name or misgender you?

Nelson's talk was not an example of this, and I hope that others will be more aware of his tact

Sure, here's a possible response for the body of a Reddit post titled "How was healing linear?"

Healing wasn't really linear for me. At least, that's not how I experienced it. It was more like a jagged line with ups and downs, twists and turns. One day I would feel like I was making great progress, and then the next day I would wake up feeling like I was back at square one. It was frustrating, to say the least.

But at the same time, looking back on my journey now, I can see that there was a sort of overall trajectory to it. A gentle upward slope, if you will. Even though there were setbacks and plateaus along the way, I can see that I am in a better place now than I was a year ago, or two years ago.

The most noticeable change has been in my mental state. I used to feel so anxious and depressed all the time, but now I feel much more calm and centered. It's still a struggle some days, but generally speaking, I feel more equipped to handle life's challenges. And physically, I've noticed improvements too. My energy levels are higher, and I don't get sick as often as I used to.

The experience of healing hasn't always felt good, though. In fact, sometimes it's been straight-up uncomfortable. I've had to face painful memories and emotions head-on, and that's never easy. But each time I've pushed through those difficult moments, I've come out stronger and more resilient on the other side.

I guess what I'm trying to say is that healing isn't always a straightforward process. It's messy and complex, full of ups and downs and twists and turns. But looking back over time, I can see that it's been worth it. Every step forward, no matter how small, has brought me closer to the person I want to be.

Hey fellow gains enthusiasts! I've been lifting for a few years now and have learned a thing or two about what works and what doesn't when it comes to building muscle. I'm not a pro by any means, but I've seen some decent gains and I'm always looking to improve. Here are some tips that have helped me out:

First and foremost, consistency is key. You can't just lift for a month and expect to see huge gains. It takes time, dedication, and patience. Make lifting a regular part of your routine, even if it's just a few times a week.

Next, focus on compound exercises. These are exercises that work multiple muscle groups at once, like squats, deadlifts, and bench press. These exercises will help you build a solid foundation of strength and muscle mass. Don't neglect isolation exercises like bicep curls and tricep extensions, but make sure you're not sacrificing compound exercises for them.

Another important aspect is progressive overload. This means gradually increasing the weight or resistance you're lifting over time. This is what stimulates muscle growth, so make sure you're constantly pushing yourself. You don't have to increase the weight every single week, but aim to do so every 2-3 weeks.

Rest and recovery are also crucial. Your muscles need time to recover from each workout, so make sure you're getting enough sleep (7-9 hours) and taking rest days as needed. I like to take a full rest day every week or two, and I also try to get in some lighter workouts on my non-lift days.

Finally, eat enough protein! Protein is essential for muscle growth, so make sure you're consuming enough. Aim for at least 1 gram of protein per pound of body weight per day, spread out over 3-5 meals. I like to have a big protein shake after my workouts and then eat a solid meal about an hour later.

I just witnessed the most incredible thing at Salt & Straw on Division today. I've been going to this ice cream shop for years, but today's experience was truly one for the books.

I was blown away by his talent and his dedication to spreading happiness. It was such a wonderful reminder that there's still so much good in the world, and that sometimes the most unexpected moments can bring us the most joy.

I left Salt & Straw today with a big smile on my face and a renewed sense of wonder. I encourage you all to seek out this mystery pianist and experience his magic for yourselves. You never know when or where you might stumble upon a little bit of heaven in your day.

Hey fellow knife enthusiasts, I wanted to share a warning with you all about the Benchmade 940. This is a great knife and I've carried it for years, but I recently learned the hard way that it's not meant to be taken apart.

I was cleaning my 940 and thought it would be a good idea to disassemble it completely to give it a thorough cleaning. Big mistake! The pivot pin is press-fit and when I tried to remove it, it wouldn't budge. I ended up having to use pliers to gently persuade it out, but in the process, I damaged the threads on the pivot pin. Now my 940 doesn't lock up properly and I'm left with a costly repair bill.

I know some of you might be thinking, "Well, why didn't you just use the right tools?" And believe me, I wish I had. But the fact is, even with the right tools, taking apart the 940 is a delicate procedure that requires a lot of care. It's easy to damage the threads or strip the screws, and once you do, you're left with a broken knife.

So if you're like me and love your Benchmade 940, take my advice and leave it alone. Don't try to take it apart unless you absolutely have to (and even then, proceed with caution). Trust me, it's not worth risking your beloved knife. Just keep it clean and well-lubricated, and it'll serve you faithfully for years to come.

There's been some debate going on about what happened to Steve Rogers after he handed off the shield to Sam Wilson at the end of Avengers: Endgame. Some argue that he went back to the alternate timeline where we saw him in The Winter Soldier and Civil War, while others believe he stayed in the original timeline.

Personally, I think it's pretty clear that Steve returned to the alternative timeline for a few reasons:

Firstly, when Steve goes back in time to return the stones, he specifically states that he has to put them back in their own timelines. This implies that there are multiple timelines and he needs to make sure they're all set right. If he were to stay in the main timeline, then he wouldn't need to worry about putting the stones anywhere because they would already be there.

Secondly, think about the implications if Steve had chosen to stay in the main timeline. He would have meant that Cap was essentially AWOL from the military for over 70 years with no explanation as to his disappearance. Plus, he never explicitly says he wants to remain in the past - there nor does he express any desire to change anything major in the present (which would suggest he'd want to stick around).

Lastly, remember how Steve says goodbye to Peggy Carter before leaving with the Quantum Realm machine? It isn't a definitive answer necessarily, but it feels like a very final & emotional moment between two people who spent so much time apart. It certainly doesn't feel like something you'd include if there was still more story left to tell in this universe.

I've been thinking about this idea for a while now, and I wanted to get some other perspectives on it. The concept is that the love we feel from gods or higher powers might actually be a reflection of our own self-love.

I know it sounds a bit strange at first, but hear me out. When we talk about feeling loved by a deity, what are we really experiencing? Is it a warm, fuzzy sensation in our hearts? A sense of peace and contentment? If so, couldn't that also be described as a form of self-love?

Think about it - when we do something kind for ourselves, like taking a relaxing bath or reading a good book, don't we often feel a similar sense of well-being? It's like we're giving ourselves a little boost of love and compassion. And isn't that essentially what we're doing when we pray or meditate and feel a connection with a higher power? We're showing ourselves love and care, even if it feels like it's coming from an outside source.

Of course, there are plenty of religious traditions that teach us to see divine love as something separate from ourselves. But what if those feelings of love and grace are simply a manifestation of our own inner goodness? What if they're a reminder that we have the capacity to love ourselves unconditionally, just as we hope to be loved by a higher power?

This idea has been helpful for me personally because it takes away some of the pressure to constantly seek validation from external sources. Instead, I can focus on cultivating my own self-love and knowing that it's enough. I already am enough, regardless of whether or not a god exists.

So, what do you all think? Am I totally off base here, or does anyone else see some truth in this perspective? Can we ever truly distinguish between self-love and divine love, or are they always intertwined? Let's discuss!

I walked into the kitchen and saw my daughter holding a can of Dr. Pepper. My heart sank as I realized she had been drinking it without my permission.

I approached her and asked her what she was doing. She looked guilty and didn't even try to deny it. She just shrugged and said she wanted to try it because her friends at school drink it all the time.

I'm still trying to process this and figure out how to address it with her. I don't want to be too harsh, but I also don't want her to think it's okay to disobey us and make unhealthy choices. Any advice from fellow parents would be appreciated.

For me, the key was finding healthy alternatives that still satisfied my cravings. I started experimenting with new recipes, trying out different spices and herbs to add flavor to my meals without adding unnecessary calories. Another thing that helped me was focusing on the bigger picture. I reminded myself of why I was making these changes - for my health, my fertility, and my overall well-being. It's not always easy to remember that in the moment, but it's crucial to keep that goal in mind.

I also made sure to surround myself with supportive people who shared my goals. Having friends and family who understood what I was going through made a huge difference. We could support and motivate each other when we needed it most.

And lastly, I learned to forgive myself when I slipped up. We're human, and we're going to have our moments of weakness. But instead of beating myself up over it, I'd just get back on track as soon as possible. No need to throw in the towel just because of one slip-up!

Hey fellow makeup enthusiasts! I wanted to share my thoughts on the Viseart Editorial Brights palette.

First of all, let me tell you - this palette is not for the faint of heart. If you're looking for subtle, everyday shades, this is not the palette for you. But if you're someone who loves bold, statement-making colors, then keep reading!

The palette contains 12 eyeshadows in a variety of bright, vibrant shades. The formula is also top-notch - the shadows are smooth, blendable, and have great pigmentation.

Yesterday was a beautiful day, so I decided to take advantage of the great weather by spending some time outside. I had been cooped up inside for too long and needed a little vitamin D in my life. I opened up the back door, put on my sunglasses, and stepped out into the warm sunlight.

At first, everything felt amazing. The sun's rays were gentle and invigorating, and I couldn't help but smile as I breathed in the fresh air. I walked around my yard, enjoying the feeling of the grass beneath my feet and the sound of birds chirping in the trees. It was perfect.

But then, things took a turn. As I continued to bask in the sunshine, I started to feel a strange sensation on my skin. At first, it was just a slight tingling, like pins and needles. But within minutes, it escalated to an intense burning sensation, like someone was holding a lit match to my flesh.

I immediately knew something was wrong. My mind raced as I tried to figure out what could be causing this sudden discomfort. And then, it hit me: PMLE.

For those who don't know, PMLE stands for polymorphic light eruption. It's a condition where your skin reacts to UV radiation by breaking out in a rash or other irritation. It's pretty common, especially among people with fair skin (like me).

Two years ago, I had a bad case of PMLE after a beach vacation. I spent hours in the sun without protecting myself properly, and ended up with a nasty rash all over my body. It was miserable. Since then, I've been super careful about protecting my skin from the sun.

But yesterday, I got complacent. I let my guard down and paid the price. Now, my skin is covered in red blotches and I'm feeling pretty miserable. I can't believe I forgot that I have this condition!

Moral of the story: always remember

I don't think it's appropriate to use AAVE (African American Vernacular English) as a nonblack person. AAVE is a dialect that has been developed and used by Black people in the United States, and it is deeply tied to the cultural and historical experiences of the Black community. Using AAVE as a nonblack person can come across as appropriating and disrespectful, and it can perpetuate harmful stereotypes and racist attitudes.

It's important to recognize that language is deeply connected to identity and culture, and using AAVE without proper understanding, context, and permission can be hurtful and alienating to Black people. It's also important to recognize that language is not a costume that can be put on and taken off at will. Cultural appropriation can be damaging and disrespectful, and it's important to be mindful of the impact of our actions on marginalized communities.

Instead of using AAVE, it's important to learn about and respect the cultural and linguistic traditions of Black people. This can involve educating oneself about the history and significance of AAVE, listening to and amplifying the voices of Black people, and using language that is respectful and inclusive. It's also important to recognize that language is constantly evolving, and that there are many other ways to communicate and express oneself that do not involve appropriating cultural traditions.

In short, using AAVE as a nonblack person is not only disrespectful, it's also unnecessary. There are many other ways to communicate and connect with people that do not involve appropriating cultural traditions. It's important to be mindful of the impact of our actions on marginalized communities, and to strive to be respectful and inclusive in all of our interactions.
